Oltre 1,6 milione di persone ha riempito la spiaggia simbolo di Rio\n\nUn fiume di persone ha riempito sabato la spiaggia di Copacabana per assistere al concerto gratuito di Madonna. La vasta distesa di sabbia di Rio de Janeiro, in Brasile, si \u00e8 trasformata in un'enorme pista da ballo. Si \u00e8 trattato dell'ultima tappa del Celebration Tour, la sua prima retrospettiva, che ha preso il via in ottobre a Londra.\n\nLa \"Regina d", "rus": "\u041d\u0430 \u043a\u043e\u043d\u0446\u0435\u0440\u0442 \u043f\u0435\u0432\u0438\u0446\u044b \u041c\u0430\u0434\u043e\u043d\u043d\u044b \u043d\u0430 \u043f\u043b\u044f\u0436\u0435 \u0432 \u0420\u0438\u043e-\u0434\u0435-\u0416\u0430\u043d\u0435\u0439\u0440\u043e \u043f\u0440\u0438\u0448\u043b\u0438 1,6 \u043c\u043b\u043d \u0447\u0435\u043b\u043e\u0432\u0435\u043a\n\n\u041d\u0430 \u043a\u043e\u043d\u0446\u0435\u0440\u0442 \u0430\u043c\u0435\u0440\u0438\u043a\u0430\u043d\u0441\u043a\u043e\u0439 \u043f\u0435\u0432\u0438\u0446\u044b \u041c\u0430\u0434\u043e\u043d\u043d\u044b, \u0441\u043e\u0441\u0442\u043e\u044f\u0432\u0448\u0438\u0439\u0441\u044f \u043d\u0430 \u043f\u043b\u044f\u0436\u0435 \u0431\u0440\u0430\u0437\u0438\u043b\u044c\u0441\u043a\u043e\u0433\u043e \u0420\u0438\u043e-\u0434\u0435-\u0416\u0430\u043d\u0435\u0439\u0440\u043e, \u043f\u0440\u0438\u0448\u043b\u0438 1,6 \u043c\u0438\u043b\u043b\u0438\u043e\u043d\u0430 \u0447\u0435\u043b\u043e\u0432\u0435\u043a. \u041e\u0431 \u044d\u0442\u043e\u043c \u0441\u043e\u043e\u0431\u0449\u0430\u0435\u0442 The Guardian.\n\n\u042d\u0442\u043e \u0431\u044b\u043b \u0437\u0430\u0432\u0435\u0440\u0448\u0430\u044e\u0449\u0438\u0439 \u043a\u043e\u043d\u0446\u0435\u0440\u0442 \u043c\u0438\u0440\u043e\u0432\u043e\u0433\u043e \u0442\u0443\u0440\u0430 Celebration, \u043d\u0430 \u043a\u043e\u0442", "por": "Nas redes sociais, um dos ritmistas compartilhou que todos receberam um t\u00eanis avaliado em 400 reais para a apresenta\u00e7\u00e3o e puderam ficar com o presente\n\nMegashow de Madonna conta com a participa\u00e7\u00e3o de artistas brasileiros no palco\n\nN\u00e3o basta desfilar na Sapuca\u00ed. {"uri": "8112434120", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "14:14:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T14:14:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T14:14:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/05/05/madonnas-biggest-ever-concert-transforms-rios-copacabana-beach-into-a-massive-dance-floor/", "title": "Madonna's biggest-ever concert transforms Rio's Copacabana beach into a massive dance floor", "body": "Madonna performs in the final show of her The Celebration Tour, on Copacabana Beach in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil on Saturday. Silvia Izquierdo/Associated Press\n\nRIO DE JANEIRO -- Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach Saturday night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans.\n\nIt was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London.\n\nThe \"Queen of Pop\" began the show with her 1998 hit \"Nothing Really Matters.\" Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers. Others held house parties in brightly lighted apartments and hotels overlooking the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead, and motorboats and sailboats anchored off the beach filled the bay.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna, 65, told the crowd. Pointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nMadonna performed her classic hits, including \"Like A Virgin\" and \"Hung Up.\" For the introduction to \"Like A Prayer,\" her head was completely covered in a black cape, a rosary gripped in her hands.\n\nThe star paid an emotional tribute to \"all the bright lights\" lost to AIDS as she sang \"Live to Tell,\" with black and white photos of people who died from the illness flashing behind her.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nLater, she was joined on stage by Brazilian artists Anitta and Pabllo Vittar.\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nAn estimated 1.6 million people attended the show, G1 reported, citing Rio City Hall's tourism agency. That is more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand.\n\nBy midday Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you.\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area was packed with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-colored cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees could hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10:37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would bring $57 million into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state - approximately 1,555 miles from Rio.\n\n\"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHeineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement. Bars and restaurants prepared \"Like a Virgin\" cocktails. A shop in the downtown neighborhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear.\n\nOrganization of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on standby. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records. Many of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time.\n\nAna Beatriz Soares, a fan who was at Copacabana on Saturday, said Madonna has made her mark across the decades.\n\n\"Madonna had to run so that today's pop artists could walk. That's why she's important because she serves as an inspiration for today's pop divas,\" Soares said.\n\n\"And that's 40 years ago. Not 40 days, 40 months. It's 40 years,\" she said.\n\nAssociated Press video journalist Douglas Engle contributed to this report.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nInvalid username/password.\n\nPlease check your email to confirm and complete your registration.\n\nCreate a commenting profile by providing an email address, password and display name. "https://www.pressherald.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/4/2024/05/Brazil_Madonna_19278_3243c0-1714918376.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9540140", "eventUri": "eng-9540140", "location": {"uri": "8113049922", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:05:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:05:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:04:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.news18.com/movies/madonna-breaks-her-personal-record-performs-for-1-6-million-people-in-free-rio-de-janeiro-concert-8879143.html", "title": "Madonna Breaks Her Personal Record, Performs For 1.6 Million People in Free Rio De Janeiro Concert - News18", "body": "Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor.\n\nMadonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach Saturday night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans.\n\nIt was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London.\n\nThe \"Queen of Pop\" began the show with her 1998 hit \"Nothing Really Matters.\" Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers. Others held house parties in brightly lighted apartments and hotels overlooking the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead, and motorboats and sailboats anchored off the beach filled the bay.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna, 65, told the crowd. Pointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nMadonna performed her classic hits, including \"Like A Virgin\" and \"Hung Up.\" For the introduction to \"Like A Prayer,\" her head was completely covered in a black cape, a rosary gripped in her hands.\n\nThe star paid an emotional tribute to \"all the bright lights\" lost to AIDS as she sang \"Live to Tell,\" with black and white photos of people who died from the illness flashing behind her.\n\nLater, she was joined on stage by Brazilian artists Anitta and Pabllo Vittar.\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nAn estimated 1.6 million people attended the show, G1 reported, citing Rio City Hall's tourism agency. That is more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand.\n\nBy midday Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you.\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area was packed with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-colored cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10:37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would vinject 293 million reals ($57 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state -- approximately 2,500 kilometers (1,555 miles) from Rio.\n\n\"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown.\n\nHeineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement. Bars and restaurants prepared \"Like a Virgin\" cocktails. A shop in the downtown neighbourhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear.\n\nOrganization of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio State's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on stand-by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records. Many of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time.\n\nAna Beatriz Soares, a fan who was at Copacabana on Saturday, said Madonna has made her mark across the decades.\n\n\"Madonna had to run so that today's pop artists could walk. That's why she's important, because she serves as an inspiration for today's pop divas,\" Soares said.\n\n\"And that's 40 years ago. Not 40 days, 40 months. It's 40 years,\" she said.\n\n(AP video journalist Douglas Engle contributed to this report.)", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News18"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8112046036", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "08:02:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T08:02:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T08:01:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/english/hollywood/news/madonnas-biggest-ever-concert-transforms-rios-copacabana-beach-into-a-massive-dance-floor/articleshow/109854997.cms", "title": "Madonna's biggest-ever concert transforms Rio's Copacabana beach into a massive dance floor | - Times of India", "body": "Madonna's free concert on Copacabana beach, the last show of The Celebration Tour, drew a vast crowd, paying tribute to AIDS victims. The event injected 293M reals into the local economy, attracting fans from around the world.Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach on Saturday night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans.\n\nIt was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London.\n\nThe \"Queen of Pop\" began the show with her 1998 hit \"Nothing Really Matters.\" Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers.\n\nOthers held house parties in brightly lighted apartments and hotels overlooking the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead, and motorboats and sailboats anchored off the beach filled the bay.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna, 65, told the crowd. Pointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nMadonna performed her classic hits, including \"Like A Virgin\" and \"Hung Up.\" For the introduction to \"Like A Prayer,\" her head was completely covered in a black cape, a rosary gripped in her hands.\n\nThe star paid an emotional tribute to \"all the bright lights\" lost to AIDS as she sang \"Live to Tell,\" with black and white photos of people who died from the illness flashing behind her.\n\nLater, she was joined on stage by Brazilian artists Anitta and Pabllo Vittar.\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nAn estimated 1.6 million people attended the show, G1 reported, citing Rio City Hall's tourism agency. That is more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand.\n\nBy midday Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you.\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area was packed with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-coloured cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10.37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would inject 293 million reals (USD 57 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98 per cent in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state - approximately 2,500 km (1,555 miles) from Rio.\n\n\"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown.\n\nHeineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement. Bars and restaurants prepared \"Like a Virgin\" cocktails. A shop in the downtown neighborhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear.\n\nOrganisation of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records.\n\nMany of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time.\n\nAna Beatriz Soares, a fan who was at Copacabana on Saturday, said Madonna has made her mark across the decades.\n\n\"Madonna had to run so that today's pop artists could walk. That's why she's important, because she serves as an inspiration for today's pop divas,\" Soares said.\n\n\"And that's 40 years ago. Not 40 days, 40 months. It's 40 years,\" she said.", "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Times of India"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@timesofindia.indiatimes.com", {"uri": "2024-05-345353296", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:39:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:39:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:29:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://entertainment.inquirer.net/554746/madonnas-biggest-ever-concert-draws-1-6-million-to-copacabana-beach", "title": "Madonna's biggest-ever concert draws 1.6 million", "body": "RIO DE JANEIRO -- Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach Saturday night, May 4, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans.\n\nIt was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London.\n\nThe \"Queen of Pop\" began the show with her 1998 hit \"Nothing Really Matters.\" Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers. Others held house parties in brightly lighted apartments and hotels overlooking the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead, and motorboats and sailboats anchored off the beach filled the bay.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna, 65, told the crowd. Pointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nMadonna performed her classic hits including \"Like a Virgin\" and \"Hung Up.\" For the introduction to \"Like a Prayer,\" her head was completely covered in a black cape, a rosary gripped in her hands.\n\nThe star paid an emotional tribute to \"all the bright lights\" lost to AIDS as she sang \"Live to Tell,\" with black-and-white photos of people who died from the illness flashing behind her.\n\nLater, she was joined on stage by Brazilian artists Anitta and Pabllo Vittar.\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nAn estimated 1.6 million people attended the show, G1 reported, citing Rio City Hall's tourism agency. That is more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand.\n\nBy midday Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you.\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area was packed with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-colored cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10:37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would inject 293 million reals ($57 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98 percent in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnb's for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state -- approximately 2,500 kilometers (1,555 miles) from Rio.\n\n\"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown.\n\nREAD: CBCP says Madonna concert is devil's work\n\nHeineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement. Bars and restaurants prepared \"Like a Virgin\" cocktails. A shop in the downtown neighborhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear.\n\nOrganization of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on standby. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records. Many of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time.\n\nAna Beatriz Soares, a fan who was at Copacabana on Saturday, said Madonna has made her mark across the decades.\n\n\"Madonna had to run so that today's pop artists could walk. That's why she's important, because she serves as an inspiration for today's pop divas,\" Soares said.\n\n\"And that's 40 years ago. Not 40 days, 40 months. {"uri": "8112009616", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "07:25:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T07:25:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T07:24:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.mid-day.com/entertainment/hollywood-news/article/madonna-biggest--ever-concert-attracts-1-6-million-people-at-rio-copacabana-beach-watch-video-23347632", "title": "Madonna's biggest-ever concert attracts 1.6 million people at Rio's Copacabana beach - watch video", "body": "Madonna began the show with her 1998 hit 'Nothing Really Matters.' Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers.\n\nMadonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach on Saturday night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans.\n\nIt was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nThe 'Queen of Pop' began the show with her 1998 hit 'Nothing Really Matters.' Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers.\n\nOthers held house parties in brightly lighted apartments and hotels overlooking the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead, and motorboats and sailboats anchored off the beach filled the bay.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna, 65, told the crowd. Pointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nMadonna performed her classic hits, including 'Like A Virgin' and 'Hung Up.' For the introduction to 'Like A Prayer,' her head was completely covered in a black cape, a rosary gripped in her hands.\n\nThe star paid an emotional tribute to 'all the bright lights' lost to AIDS as she sang 'Live to Tell,' with black and white photos of people who died from the illness flashing behind her.\n\nLater, she was joined on stage by Brazilian artists Anitta and Pabllo Vittar.\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance. An estimated 1.6 million people attended the show, G1 reported, citing Rio City Hall's tourism agency. That is more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand.\n\nBy midday Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area was packed with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-coloured cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10.37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would inject 293 million reals (USD 57 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98 per cent in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement.\n\nRio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state, approximately 2,500 km (1,555 miles) from Rio.\n\n\"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown.\n\nHeineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement. Bars and restaurants prepared \u00bfLike a Virgin\u00bf cocktails. A shop in the downtown neighborhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear.\n\nOrganisation of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records.\n\nMany of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time.\n\nAna Beatriz Soares, a fan who was at Copacabana on Saturday, said Madonna has made her mark across the decades.\n\n\"Madonna had to run so that today's pop artists could walk. That's why she's important because she serves as an inspiration for today's pop divas,\" Soares said.\n\n\"And that's 40 years ago. Not 40 days, 40 months. {"uri": "8111965842", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "06:39:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T06:39:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T06:38:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/headlines/2927989-madonnas-epic-concert-electrifies-rios-copacabana-transforming-it-into-a-colossal-dance-party", "title": "Madonna's Epic Concert Electrifies Rio's Copacabana, Transforming It into a Colossal Dance Party | Headlines", "body": "Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach on Saturday night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans. It was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London. The \"Queen of Pop\" began the show with her 1998 hit \"Nothing Really Matters.\" Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers. Others held house parties in brightly lighted apartments and hotels overlooking the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead, and motorboats and sailboats anchored off the beach filled the bay. \"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna, 65, told the crowd. Pointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.'' Madonna performed her classic hits, including \"Like A Virgin\" and \"Hung Up.\" For the introduction to \"Like A Prayer,\" her head was completely covered in a black cape, a rosary gripped in her hands. The star paid an emotional tribute to \"all the bright lights\" lost to AIDS as she sang \"Live to Tell,\" with black and white photos of people who died from the illness flashing behind her. Later, she was joined on stage by Brazilian artists Anitta and Pabllo Vittar. Rio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nAn estimated 1.6 million people attended the show, G1 reported, citing Rio City Hall's tourism agency. That is more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand. By midday Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you.\" Flags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area was packed with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun. \"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-coloured cone bra and a black cap. \"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area. Eighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10.37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule. City Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would inject 293 million reals (USD 57 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98 per cent in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement. \"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state -- approximately 2,500 km (1,555 miles) from Rio. \"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown. Heineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement. Bars and restaurants prepared \"Like a Virgin\" cocktails. A shop in the downtown neighborhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear.\n\nOrganisation of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records. Many of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time.\n\nAna Beatriz Soares, a fan who was at Copacabana on Saturday, said Madonna has made her mark across the decades. \"Madonna had to run so that today's pop artists could walk. That's why she's important, because she serves as an inspiration for today's pop divas,'' Soares said. ''And that's 40 years ago. Not 40 days, 40 months. It's 40 years,\" she said.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8111836369", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "04:02:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T04:02:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T04:01:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/madonna-puts-on-free-concert-in-rio-turning-copacabana-beach-into-enormous-dance-floor/article_73173ccc-ddb4-5b1f-9b71-d08081a2c771.html", "title": "Madonna puts on free concert in Rio, turning Copacabana beach into enormous dance floor", "body": "A fan of Madonna, wearing a mask, strikes a pose during a rehearsal for Madonna's The Celebration Tour, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Thursday, May 2, 2024. Madonna will conclude her tour on Saturday with a free concert at Copacabana Beach.\n\nRIO DE JANEIRO (AP) -- Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach Saturday night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans.\n\nIt was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London.\n\nThe \"Queen of Pop\" began the show with her 1998 hit \"Nothing Really Matters.\" Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers. Others looked on from brightly lighted apartments and hotels lining the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna told the crowd. Pointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nRio's City Hall predicted 1.5 million spectators, more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand.\n\nBy midday Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you.\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area teemedwith street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-colored cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10:37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would vinject 293 million reals ($57 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state -- approximately 2,500 kilometers (1,555 miles) from Rio.\n\n\"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown.\n\nHeineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement. Bars and restaurants prepared \"Like a Virgin\" cocktails, named for her 1984 hit. A shop in the downtown neighborhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear.\n\nOrganization of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records. Many of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-345325941", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:32:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:32:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T05:58:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/madonnas-biggest-ever-concert-transforms-rios-copacabana-beach-into-a-massive-dance-floor/article_f361d2d8-af0d-5748-9ab5-e1d4b9dba525.html", "title": "Madonna's biggest-ever concert transforms Rio's Copacabana beach into a massive dance floor", "body": "RIO DE JANEIRO (AP) -- Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach Saturday night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans.\n\nIt was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London.\n\nThe \"Queen of Pop\" began the show with her 1998 hit \"Nothing Really Matters.\" Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers. Others held house parties in brightly lighted apartments and hotels overlooking the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead, and motorboats and sailboats anchored off the beach filled the bay.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna, 65, told the crowd. Pointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nMadonna performed her classic hits, including \"Like A Virgin\" and \"Hung Up.\" For the introduction to \"Like A Prayer,\" her head was completely covered in a black cape, a rosary gripped in her hands.\n\nThe star paid an emotional tribute to \"all the bright lights\" lost to AIDS as she sang \"Live to Tell,\" with black and white photos of people who died from the illness flashing behind her.\n\nLater, she was joined on stage by Brazilian artists Anitta and Pabllo Vittar.\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nAn estimated 1.6 million people attended the show, G1 reported, citing Rio City Hall's tourism agency. That is more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand.\n\nBy midday Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you.\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area was packed with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-colored cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10:37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would vinject 293 million reals ($57 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state -- approximately 2,500 kilometers (1,555 miles) from Rio.\n\n\"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown.\n\nHeineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement. Bars and restaurants prepared \"Like a Virgin\" cocktails. A shop in the downtown neighborhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear.\n\nOrganization of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records. Many of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time.\n\nAna Beatriz Soares, a fan who was at Copacabana on Saturday, said Madonna has made her mark across the decades.\n\n\"Madonna had to run so that today's pop artists could walk. That's why she's important, because she serves as an inspiration for today's pop divas,\" Soares said.\n\n\"And that's 40 years ago. Not 40 days, 40 months. It's 40 years,\" she said.\n\nAP video journalist Douglas Engle contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, {"uri": "8111931321", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "06:01:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T06:01:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T06:01:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/entertainment/entertainment-news/2024/05/04/madonnas-biggestever-concert-transforms-rios-copacabana-beach-into-a-massive-dance-floor/", "title": "Madonna's biggest-ever concert transforms Rio's Copacabana beach into a massive dance floor - Medicine Hat News", "body": "SUBSCRIBE NOW RIO DE JANEIRO (AP) - Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach Saturday night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans. It was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London. The \"Queen of Pop\"\u009d began the show with her 1998 hit \"Nothing Really Matters.\"\u009d Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers. Others held house parties in brightly lighted apartments and hotels overlooking the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead, and motorboats and sailboats anchored off the beach filled the bay. \"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\"\u009d Madonna, 65, told the crowd. Pointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\" Madonna performed her classic hits, including \"Like A Virgin\"\u009d and \"Hung Up.\"\u009d For the introduction to \"Like A Prayer,\"\u009d her head was completely covered in a black cape, a rosary gripped in her hands. The star paid an emotional tribute to \"all the bright lights\"\u009d lost to AIDS as she sang \"Live to Tell,\"\u009d with black and white photos of people who died from the illness flashing behind her. Later, she was joined on stage by Brazilian artists Anitta and Pabllo Vittar. Rio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance. An estimated 1.6 million people attended the show, G1 reported, citing Rio City Hall's tourism agency. That is more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career. In recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand. By midday Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you.\"\u009d Flags with \"Madonna\"\u009d printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area was packed with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun. \"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\"\u009d said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-colored cone bra and a black cap. \"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\"\u009d said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area. Eighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10:37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule. City Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would vinject 293 million reals ($57 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement. \"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\"\u009d said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state - approximately 2,500 kilometers (1,555 miles) from Rio. \"Welcome Queen!\"\u009d read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown. Heineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement. Bars and restaurants prepared \"Like a Virgin\"\u009d cocktails. A shop in the downtown neighborhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear. Organization of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show. Rio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show. A number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records. Many of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time. Ana Beatriz Soares, a fan who was at Copacabana on Saturday, said Madonna has made her mark across the decades. \"Madonna had to run so that today's pop artists could walk. That's why she's important, because she serves as an inspiration for today's pop divas,\" Soares said. \"And that's 40 years ago. Not 40 days, 40 months. It's 40 years,\"\u009d she said. ___ AP video journalist Douglas Engle contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine Hat News"}, {"uri": "2024-05-346140329", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:38:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:38:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T07:38:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://gulftoday.ae/culture/2024/05/06/madonna-wows-rio-with-celebration-tour-finale", "title": "Madonna wows Rio with 'Celebration Tour' finale", "body": "US pop star Madonna performs onstage during a free concert at Copacabana beach in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. AFP\n\nPop idol Madonna gave it all in Rio de Janeiro as she looked back on her four-decade career in a historic show before throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana beach on Saturday night.\n\nThe 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel shortly after 10:30 pm (0130 GMT Sunday) to a massive stage for one of the most important shows of her career.\n\nDressed all in black, Madonna broke into her hit \"Nothing Really Matters\" at the start of a burst of brute energy.\n\n\"Rio, here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" she said at the start of a performance that brought the giddy Brazilian audience to its feet.\n\nThe show marked the final stop on her \"Celebration Tour\" noting her 40 years atop pop charts, in a free event that drew an estimated 1.6 million people from across Brazil, according to the city tourism office.\n\nFans cheer as US pop star Madonna performs during a free concert at Copacabana beach.\n\nBilled as a \"historic\" show, it blended music and dance with cabaret.\n\nLive To Tell\n\nMadonna was joined on stage during the performance of her hit \"Vogue\" by Brazilian singer Anitta, who is known for taking Carioca funk -- the soundtrack of Rio's favelas -- to the rest of the world.\n\nWith \"Live To Tell\", she paid tribute to AIDS victims, including Freddie Mercury and the legendary Brazilian musician Cazuza.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands jostled to get a view of the stage. Boats bobbed in the water offshore, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder was Madonna's phrase: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimize the usual mass robberies.\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection in June last year.\n\nOi, Rio\n\nMadonna's concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million production cost.\n\nA crowd of fans is seen as US pop star Madonna performs during a free concert at Copacabana beach in Rio de Janeiro.\n\nAuthorities expected it would pump a far larger sum -- 293 million reales, or $57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood were billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nHundreds of her fans swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace since her arrival on Monday.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.\n\nThe response on Saturday night from more than a million voices: \"Oi, Queen Madonna!\"", "source": {"uri": "gulftoday.ae", "dataType": {"uri": "8111882302", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "05:03:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T05:03:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T05:02:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.hjnews.com/world/madonna-puts-on-free-concert-in-rio-turning-copacabana-beach-into-enormous-dance-floor/article_b4b95e00-1407-5833-b022-03890b05cbc1.html", "title": "Madonna puts on free concert in Rio, turning Copacabana beach into enormous dance floor", "body": "RIO DE JANEIRO (AP) -- Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach Saturday night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans.\n\nIt was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London.\n\nThe \"Queen of Pop\" began the show with her 1998 hit \"Nothing Really Matters.\" Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers. Others held house parties in brightly lighted apartments and hotels overlooking the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead, and motorboats and sailboats anchored off the beach filled the bay.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna told the crowd. Pointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nMadonna performed her classic hits, including \"Like A Virgin\" and \"Hung Up.\" For the introduction to \"Like A Prayer,\" her head was completely covered in a black cape, a rosary gripped in her hands.\n\nThe star paid an emotional tribute to \"all the bright lights\" lost to AIDS as she sang \"Live to Tell,\" with black and white photos of people who died from the illness flashing behind her.\n\nLater, she was joined on stage by Brazilian artists Anitta and Pabllo Vittar.\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nRio's City Hall predicted 1.5 million spectators, more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand.\n\nBy midday Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you.\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area was packed with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-colored cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10:37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would vinject 293 million reals ($57 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state -- approximately 2,500 kilometers (1,555 miles) from Rio.\n\n\"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown.\n\nHeineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement. Bars and restaurants prepared \"Like a Virgin\" cocktails. A shop in the downtown neighborhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear.\n\nOrganization of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records. Many of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time.\n\nAna Beatriz Soares, a fan who was at Copacabana on Saturday, said Madonna has made her mark across the decades.\n\n\"Madonna had to run so that today's pop artists could walk. That's why she's important, because she serves as an inspiration for today's pop divas,\" Soares said.\n\n\"And that's 40 years ago. Not 40 days, 40 months. It's 40 years,\" she said.\n\nAP video journalist Douglas Engle contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "hjnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Herald Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8112985876", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "01:34:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T01:34:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T01:34:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://celebrity.nine.com.au/latest/madonna-news-singer-performs-biggest-ever-concert-rio-de-janeiro-copacabana-beach-record-breaking/2e1778ae-b7e5-47f5-a1d3-8a3b97e2cbb6", "title": "Record-breaking amount of people gather just to glimpse Madonna", "body": "Madonna draws record-breaking crowd of 1.6 million for biggest concert of her career: 'Who knows if she'll ever come back'\n\nMadonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach over the weekend, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans.\n\nIt was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London.\n\nThe 'Queen of Pop' began the Saturday night (Sunday in Australia) show with her 1998 hit Nothing Really Matters. Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers. Others held house parties in brightly lighted apartments and hotels overlooking the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead, and motorboats and sailboats anchored off the beach filled the bay.\n\nREAD MORE: Kate Beckinsale hits back at bullying and plastic surgery claims\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna, 65, told the crowd. Pointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nMadonna performed her classic hits, including Like A Virgin and Hung Up. For the introduction to Like A Prayer, her head was completely covered in a black cape, a rosary gripped in her hands.\n\nThe star paid an emotional tribute to \"all the bright lights\" lost to AIDS as she sang Live to Tell, with black and white photos of people who died from the illness flashing behind her.\n\nFor a daily dose of 9Honey, subscribe to our newsletter here\n\nLater, she was joined on stage by Brazilian artists Anitta and Pabllo Vittar.\n\nOnce off stage, Madonna took to Instagram to share a message with her 19.7 million followers.\n\n\"This really happened..........Thank you Rio \ud83c\udde7\ud83c\uddf7\ud83d\udc9b .......... Thank you [Vittar] and [Anitta] ...............Words cannot express my gratitude! To everyone involved!! \ud83c\udde7\ud83c\uddf7\ud83d\udc9b\ud83c\udde7\ud83c\uddf7\ud83d\udc9a,\" she wrote alongside footage of her performance and the record-breaking crowd.\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nIN PICTURES: All the celebrity sightings at 2024 F1 Grand Prix in Miami\n\nREAD MORE: Every royal family member has enjoyed a popularity boost - except one\n\nAn estimated 1.6 million people attended the show, G1 reported, citing Rio City Hall's tourism agency. That is more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand.\n\nBy midday on Saturday (Sunday in Australia), fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you.\"\n\nFlags with 'Madonna' printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area was packed with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-coloured cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10:37pm local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would inject 293 million reals (approx. $87 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98 per cent in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1 to 6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state - approximately 2500 kilometres from Rio.\n\n\"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown.\n\nHeineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement. Bars and restaurants prepared 'Like a Virgin' cocktails. A shop in the downtown neighbourhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear.\n\nREAD MORE: Inside the abandoned 'Disneyland neighbourhood' with over 500 homes\n\nREAD MORE: The big ticket items worth buying Mum this Mother's Day\n\nOrganisation of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio state's security plan included the presence of 3200 military personnel and 1500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than four million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records. Many of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time.\n\nAna Beatriz Soares, a fan who was at Copacabana on Saturday (Sunday in Australia), said Madonna has made her mark across the decades.\n\n\"Madonna had to run so that today's pop artists could walk. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand.\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area was packed with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10:37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would vinject 293 million reals ($57 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98 percent in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state, approximately 2,500 kilometers from Rio.\n\n\"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown.\n\nBars and restaurants prepared \"Like a Virgin\" cocktails. A shop in the downtown neighborhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear.\n\nOrganization of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records.\n\nMany of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time.", "source": {"uri": "hurriyetdailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Hurriyet Daily News"}, "authors": [], "concepts":
