{"uri": "8112067171", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "08:22:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T08:22:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T08:22:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://tribune.net.ph/2024/05/05/madonna-wows-rio-with-celebration-tour-finale", "title": "Madonna wows Rio with 'Celebration Tour' finale", "body": "US pop star Madonna performs onstage during a free concert at Copacabana beach in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, on 4 May 2024. Madonna ended her \"The Celebration Tour\" with a performance attended by some 1.5 million enthusiastic fans. Pablo PORCIUNCULA / AFP\n\nPop idol Madonna gave it all in Rio de Janeiro as she looked back on her four-decade career in a historic show before throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana beach on Saturday night.\n\nThe 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel shortly after 10:30 p.m. (0130 GMT Sunday) to a massive stage for one of the most important shows of her career.\n\nDressed all in black, Madonna broke into her hit \"Nothing Really Matters\" at the start of a burst of brute energy.\n\n\"Rio, here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" she said at the start of a performance that brought the giddy Brazilian audience to its feet.\n\nThe show marked the final stop on her \"Celebration Tour\" noting her 40 years atop pop charts, in a free event that was estimated to draw upward of 1.5 million fans from across Brazil.\n\nBilled as a \"historic\" show, it blended music and dance with cabaret.\n\nMadonna showcased her versatility with dozens of set and costume changes, spectacular lights and many giant screens along the beach.\n\nShe went from being dressed as a schoolgirl in a miniskirt to an irreverent Christian in a black cape while luminous crosses circled around her during \"Like a Prayer,\" a song that cost her excommunication from the Catholic Church.\n\nLive To Tell\n\nMadonna was joined on stage during the performance of her hit \"Vogue\" by Brazilian singer Anitta, who is known for taking Carioca funk -- the soundtrack of Rio's favelas -- to the rest of the world.\n\nWith \"Live To Tell\", she paid tribute to AIDS victims, including Freddie Mercury and the legendary Brazilian musician Cazuza.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands jostled to get a view of the stage.\n\nBoats bobbed in the water offshore, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP.\n\nTattooed on her shoulder was Madonna's phrase: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a transgender woman, standing near the huge stage that was twice the size of any other used on the tour.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimize the usual mass robberies.\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection in June last year.\n\nMadonna has released an album every two or three years since the 1984 release of \"Like a Virgin.\"\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar.\n\nBut the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, such as when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video \"Like a Prayer,\" which was seen as blasphemous.\n\nOi, Rio!\n\nMadonna's concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million Reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million production cost.\n\nAuthorities expected it would pump a far larger sum -- 293 million Reales, or $57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood were billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nHundreds of her fans swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace since her arrival on Monday.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.\n\nThe response on Saturday night from more than a million voices: \"Oi, Queen Madonna!\"", "source": {"uri": "tribune.net.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8113687266", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "11:26:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T11:26:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T11:25:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.celebitchy.com/870377/16_million_people_attended_madonnas_free_concert_in_rio/", "title": "1.6 million people attended Madonna's free concert in Rio", "body": "As mentioned last week, Madonna has come to the end of her Celebration Tour. After 80 ticketed shows, two continents, and two lawsuits for starting late (resolutions still pending), all that was left was a free concert in Rio on May 4. And how did it go? An estimated 1.6 million people attended last Saturday's show. We'll never know how much it was the power of Madonna, the appeal of free tickets, or some combination of both. But reports indicate that the revelry was joyful in the days leading up to the concert and on the night of, when Madge took to the stage only 52 minutes late! That's basically on time for her, right? Associated Press captured highlights of the scene at Copacabana beach:\n\nMadonna takes a bow: Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach Saturday night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans. ... Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers. Others held house parties in brightly lighted apartments and hotels overlooking the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead, and motorboats and sailboats anchored off the beach filled the bay. \"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna, 65, told the crowd. Pointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"this place is magic.\"\n\nMadge's previous audience record was broken: An estimated 1.6 million people attended the show, G1 reported, citing Rio City Hall's tourism agency. That is more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nCopacabana beach got into the groove: In recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside that stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand. ... Flags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area was packed with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun. ... Eighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10:37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nRio followed NYE holiday planning: Organization of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show. Rio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA fan justifies her love: Ana Beatriz Soares, a fan who was at Copacabana on Saturday said Madonna has made her mark across the decades. \"Madonna had to run so that today's pop artists could walk. That's why she's important, because she serves as an inspiration for today's pop divas,\" Soares said.\n\n[From Associated Press]\n\nYou guys, I know there may be a second language issue here, but I am positively howling at the statement, \"Madonna had to run so that today's pop artists could walk.\" We have to keep it, it's too good! So instead of paving the way for artists to follow, Madonna flew high so that others could trudge after her? I think Madonna would (not so) secretly endorse this twist on the popular phrase. I can just see her going, \"Hey Gaga, I ran so you could walk!\" Anyway, it sounds like it was everything you'd want for a final show, with millions of fans excited to be there. And I guess having the concert be free somehow removed the pressure for Madge to start on time. At least that's what I'm going with. Or Rio really is magical enough that even Madonna can begin within an hour of the scheduled start time (which was 9:45pm). Lastly, kudos to the AP writer for subtly referencing the Christ the Redeemer statue in an article about 1.6 million people turning out to worship a pop idol. {"uri": "8112127362", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:20:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:20:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:20:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/madonna-wows-rio-with-celebration-tour-finale/article_d4396087-c743-5caf-b2c9-816fd966bad6.html", "title": "Madonna wows Rio with 'Celebration Tour' finale", "body": "Aerial view shows the crowd before US pop star Madonna's free concert in Rio de Janeiro\n\nPop idol Madonna gave it all in Rio de Janeiro as she looked back on her four-decade career in a historic show before throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana beach on Saturday night.\n\nThe 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel shortly after 10:30 pm (0130 GMT Sunday) to a massive stage for one of the most important shows of her career.\n\nDressed all in black, Madonna broke into her hit \"Nothing Really Matters\" at the start of a burst of brute energy.\n\n\"Rio, here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" she said at the start of a performance that brought the giddy Brazilian audience to its feet.\n\nThe show marked the final stop on her \"Celebration Tour\" noting her 40 years atop pop charts, in a free event that was estimated to draw upward of 1.5 million fans from across Brazil.\n\nBilled as a \"historic\" show, it blended music and dance with cabaret.\n\nMadonna showcased her versatility with dozens of set and costume changes, spectacular lights and many giant screens along the beach.\n\nShe went from being dressed as a schoolgirl in a miniskirt to an irreverent Christian in a black cape while luminous crosses circled around her during \"Like a Prayer,\" a song that cost her excommunication from the Catholic Church.\n\n- 'Live To Tell' -\n\nMadonna was joined on stage during the performance of her hit \"Vogue\" by Brazilian singer Anitta, who is known for taking Carioca funk -- the soundtrack of Rio's favelas -- to the rest of the world.\n\nWith \"Live To Tell\", she paid tribute to AIDS victims, including Freddie Mercury and the legendary Brazilian musician Cazuza.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands jostled to get a view of the stage. Boats bobbed in the water offshore, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder was Madonna's phrase: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a transgender woman, standing near the huge stage that was twice the size of any other used on the tour.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimize the usual mass robberies.\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection in June last year.\n\nMadonna has released an album every two or three years since the 1984 release of \"Like a Virgin.\"\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, such as when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video \"Like a Prayer,\" which was seen as blasphemous.\n\n- 'Oi, Rio!' -\n\nMadonna's concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million production cost.\n\nAuthorities expected it would pump a far larger sum -- 293 million reales, or $57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood were billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nHundreds of her fans swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace since her arrival on Monday.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.\n\nThat scene was repeated on Friday.\n\n\"Oi, Rio!\" she called out in Portuguese to fans.\n\nThe response on Saturday night from more than a million voices: \"Oi, Queen Madonna!\"\n\nll/app/sn/pbt", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": {"uri": "8111816014", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:31:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:31:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:31:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/entertainment/entertainment-news/2024/05/04/madonna-puts-on-free-concert-in-rio-turning-copacabana-beach-into-enormous-dance-floor/", "title": "Madonna puts on free concert in Rio, turning Copacabana beach into enormous dance floor - Medicine Hat News", "body": "SUBSCRIBE NOW RIO DE JANEIRO (AP) - Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach Saturday night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans. It was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London. The \"Queen of Pop\"\u009d began the show with her 1998 hit \"Nothing Really Matters. Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers. Others looked on from brightly lighted apartments and hotels lining the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead. \"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\"\u009d Madonna told the crowd. \"The ocean, the mountains. Jesus, this place is magic.\" Rio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance. Rio's City Hall predicted 1.5 million spectators, more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career. In recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand. By midday Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you.\"\u009d Flags with \"Madonna\"\u009d printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area teemedwith street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun. \"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\"\u009d said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-colored cone bra and a black cap. \"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\"\u009d said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area. Eighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10:37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule. City Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would vinject 293 million reals ($57 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement. \"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\"\u009d said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state - approximately 2,500 kilometers (1,555 miles) from Rio. \"Welcome Queen!\"\u009d read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown. Heineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement. Bars and restaurants prepared \"Like a Virgin\"\u009d cocktails, named for her 1984 hit. A shop in the downtown neighborhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear. Organization of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show. Rio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show. A number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records. Many of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time.", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine Hat News"}, "authors": [{"uri": Others looked on from brightly lighted apartments and hotels lining the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna told the crowd.\n\nPointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nRio's City Hall predicted 1.5 million spectators, more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987.\n\nMadonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. They danced on the sand during the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel.\n\nBy midday on Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying: \"Welcome, Madonna. You are the best. I love you.\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black-and-white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area teemed with street vendors, and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-coloured cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure all attendees could hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10.37pm local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would inject 293 million reals (\u00a346 million) into the local economy.\n\nHotel capacity was expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association.\n\nFans from Brazil, Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement.\n\nRio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights for the first week of May from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna; who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state -- approximately 1,555 miles from Rio.\n\nRSS Syndicated {"uri": "8112231155", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "10:59:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T10:59:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T10:58:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://manilastandard.net/showbitz/music-concerts/314443401/madonna-wows-rio-with-celebration-tour-finale.html", "title": "Madonna wows Rio with 'Celebration Tour' finale - Manila Standard", "body": "Rio de Janeiro, Brazil -- Pop idol Madonna gave it all in Rio de Janeiro as she looked back on her four-decade career in a historic show before throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana beach on Saturday night.\n\nThe 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel shortly after 10:30 pm (0130 GMT Sunday) to a massive stage for one of the most important shows of her career.\n\nDressed all in black, Madonna broke into her hit \"Nothing Really Matters\" at the start of a burst of brute energy.\n\n\"Rio, here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" she said at the start of a performance that brought the giddy Brazilian audience to its feet.\n\nThe show marked the final stop on her \"Celebration Tour\" noting her 40 years atop pop charts, in a free event that was estimated to draw upward of 1.5 million fans from across Brazil.\n\nBilled as a \"historic\" show, it blended music and dance with cabaret.\n\nMadonna showcased her versatility with dozens of set and costume changes, spectacular lights and many giant screens along the beach.\n\nShe went from being dressed as a schoolgirl in a miniskirt to an irreverent Christian in a black cape while luminous crosses circled around her during \"Like a Prayer,\" a song that cost her excommunication from the Catholic Church.\n\n'Live To Tell'\n\nMadonna was joined on stage during the performance of her hit \"Vogue\" by Brazilian singer Anitta, who is known for taking Carioca funk -- the soundtrack of Rio's favelas -- to the rest of the world.\n\nWith \"Live To Tell,\" she paid tribute to AIDS victims, including Freddie Mercury and the legendary Brazilian musician Cazuza.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands jostled to get a view of the stage. Boats bobbed in the water offshore, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told Agence France Presse (AFP). Tattooed on her shoulder was Madonna's phrase: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a transgender woman, standing near the huge stage that was twice the size of any other used on the tour.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimize the usual mass robberies.\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection in June last year.\n\nMadonna has released an album every two or three years since the 1984 release of \"Like a Virgin.\"\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, such as when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nMadonna's irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video \"Like a Prayer,\" which was seen as blasphemous.\n\n'Oi, Rio!'\n\nMadonna's concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million production cost.\n\nAuthorities expected it would pump a far larger sum -- 293 million reales, or $57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood were billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nHundreds of her fans have swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace since her arrival on Monday.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.\n\nThe response on Saturday night from more than a million voices: \"Oi, Queen Madonna!\"", "source": {"uri": "manilastandard.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Manila Standard"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madonna", "type": "wiki", {"uri": "2024-05-345542742", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "11:11:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T11:11:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T07:33:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/madonna-wows-rio-with-celebration-tour-finale/article_4a80e3c4-b79f-5c26-acc5-25d7b5f9e541.html", "title": "Madonna wows Rio with 'Celebration Tour' finale", "body": "Aerial view shows the crowd before US pop star Madonna's free concert in Rio de Janeiro\n\nPop idol Madonna gave it all in Rio de Janeiro as she looked back on her four-decade career in a historic show before throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana beach on Saturday night.\n\nThe 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel shortly after 10:30 pm (0130 GMT Sunday) to a massive stage for one of the most important shows of her career.\n\nDressed all in black, Madonna broke into her hit \"Nothing Really Matters\" at the start of a burst of brute energy.\n\n\"Rio, here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" she said at the start of a performance that brought the giddy Brazilian audience to its feet.\n\nThe show marked the final stop on her \"Celebration Tour\" noting her 40 years atop pop charts, in a free event that was estimated to draw upward of 1.5 million fans from across Brazil.\n\nBilled as a \"historic\" show, it blended music and dance with cabaret.\n\nMadonna showcased her versatility with dozens of set and costume changes, spectacular lights and many giant screens along the beach.\n\nShe went from being dressed as a schoolgirl in a miniskirt to an irreverent Christian in a black cape while luminous crosses circled around her during \"Like a Prayer,\" a song that cost her excommunication from the Catholic Church.\n\n- 'Live To Tell' -\n\nMadonna was joined on stage during the performance of her hit \"Vogue\" by Brazilian singer Anitta, who is known for taking Carioca funk -- the soundtrack of Rio's favelas -- to the rest of the world.\n\nWith \"Live To Tell\", she paid tribute to AIDS victims, including Freddie Mercury and the legendary Brazilian musician Cazuza.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands jostled to get a view of the stage. Boats bobbed in the water offshore, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder was Madonna's phrase: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a transgender woman, standing near the huge stage that was twice the size of any other used on the tour.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimize the usual mass robberies.\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection in June last year.\n\nMadonna has released an album every two or three years since the 1984 release of \"Like a Virgin.\"\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, such as when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video \"Like a Prayer,\" which was seen as blasphemous.\n\n- 'Oi, Rio!' -\n\nMadonna's concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million production cost.\n\nAuthorities expected it would pump a far larger sum -- 293 million reales, or $57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood were billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nHundreds of her fans swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace since her arrival on Monday.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.\n\nThat scene was repeated on Friday.\n\n\"Oi, Rio!\" she called out in Portuguese to fans.\n\nThe response on Saturday night from more than a million voices: \"Oi, Queen Madonna!\"\n\nll/app/sn/pbt\n\nMore from this section\n\nArizona's Democratic governor signs a bill to repeal 1864 across Brazil.\n\nBilled as a \"historic\" show, it blended music and dance with cabaret.\n\nMadonna showcased her versatility with dozens of set and costume changes, spectacular lights and many giant {"uri": "8113461478", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "09:00:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T09:00:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T08:59:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://news.stv.tv/entertainment/madonna-puts-on-free-concert-for-1-6-million-fans-in-rio-de-janeiro", "title": "Madonna puts on free concert for 1.6 million fans in Rio de Janeiro", "body": "Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach on Saturday night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans.\n\nIt was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London.\n\nThe \"Queen of Pop\" began the show with her 1998 hit \"Nothing Really Matters.\" Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers.\n\nOthers held house parties in brightly lighted apartments and hotels overlooking the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead, and motorboats and sailboats anchored off the beach filled the bay.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna, 65, told the crowd. Pointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nMadonna performed her classic hits, including \"Like A Virgin\" and \"Hung Up.\" For the introduction to \"Like A Prayer,\" her head was completely covered in a black cape, a rosary gripped in her hands.\n\nThe star paid an emotional tribute to \"all the bright lights\" lost to AIDS as she sang \"Live to Tell,\" with black and white photos of people who died from the illness flashing behind her.\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nAn estimated 1.6 million people attended the show, G1 reported, citing Rio City Hall's tourism agency.\n\nThat is more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star.\n\nDuring the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand.\n\nBy midday Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you.\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies.\n\nThe area was packed with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10:37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would vinject 293 million reals ($57 million) into the local economy. H\n\notel capacity was expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement.\n\nRio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\nRio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records.\n\nMany of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's {"uri": "8113134538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "04:38:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T04:38:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T04:37:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://tnp.straitstimes.com/entertainment/music/madonna-wows-16-million-fans-rios-concert", "title": "Madonna wows 1.6 million fans at Rio's concert", "body": "RIO DE JANEIRO - Pop idol Madonna gave it all in Rio de Janeiro as she looked back on her four-decade career in a historic show before throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana beach on May 4.\n\nThe 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel to a massive stage for one of the most important shows of her career.\n\nDressed all in black, Madonna broke into her hit Nothing Really Matters (1998) at the start with a burst of brute energy.\n\n\"Rio, here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" she said at the start of a performance that brought the giddy Brazilian audience to its feet.\n\nThe show marked the final stop on her Celebration Tour noting her 40 years atop the pop charts, in a free event that drew an estimated 1.6 million people from across Brazil, according to the city tourism office.\n\nBilled as a \"historic\" show, it blended music and dance with cabaret.\n\nMadonna showcased her versatility with dozens of set and costume changes, spectacular lights and many giant screens along the beach.\n\nShe went from being dressed as a schoolgirl in a miniskirt to an irreverent Christian in a black cape while luminous crosses circled around her during Like A Prayer (1989), a song that cost her excommunication from the Catholic Church.\n\nMadonna was joined on stage during the performance of her hit Vogue (1990) by Brazilian singer Anitta, who is known for taking Carioca funk - the soundtrack of Rio's favelas - to the rest of the world.\n\nWith Live To Tell (1986), she paid tribute to Aids victims, including British singer Freddie Mercury and the legendary Brazilian musician Cazuza.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands jostled to get a view of the stage. Boats bobbed in the water offshore, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder was Madonna's phrase: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimise the usual mass robberies.\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection in June 2023.\n\nMadonna has released an album every two or three years since the 1984 release of Like A Virgin.\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, such as when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nMadonna's concert should provide an economic boost to Rio. State and city governments said they spent 20 million reais (S$5.3 million) on the concert, while the rest was financed by private sponsors.\n\nThe authorities expected it would pump a far larger sum - 293 million reais - into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighbourhood were billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nHundreds of her fans swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace since her arrival on April 29.\n\nThe excitement spiked on May 2 night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colourful balaclava.\n\nThe response on May 4 night from more than a million voices: \"Oi, Queen Madonna!\" - AFP", {"uri": "8112207104", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "10:36:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T10:36:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T10:35:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/madonna-ends-celebration-tour-biggest-102907493.html", "title": "Madonna ends Celebration tour with biggest ever show to over a million fans at Rio's Copacabana beach", "body": "Madonna performed her biggest ever show, closing her Celebration world tour in front of 1.6 million fans with free tickets on Rio's Copacabana beach.\n\nDespite starting 50 minutes late, Madonna packed over 20 songs from 15 albums into her show and was joined on stage by Latin star Anitta to perform \"Vogue\".\n\nThe 65-year-old began the tour in London last October and has been performing an eclectic mix of her catalogue on dates around the world.\n\nThe Copacabana show dwarfed her previous record crowd of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna told the crowd.\n\nPointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nAn estimated 1.6 million people attended the gig, more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987.\n\nMadonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star.\n\nBy midday on Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying: \"Welcome, Madonna. You are the best. I love you.\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black-and-white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area teemed with street vendors, and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-coloured cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure all attendees could hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10.37pm local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would inject 293 million reals (\u00a346 million) into the local economy.\n\nHotel capacity was expected to reach 98 per cent in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association.\n\nFans from Brazil, Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement.\n\nRio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights for the first week of May from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a {"uri": "2024-05-345317337", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:31:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:31:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:30:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.1news.co.nz/2024/05/05/madonna-kicks-off-biggest-ever-beach-concert-in-rio/", "title": "Madonna kicks off biggest-ever beach concert in Rio", "body": "Madonna will give a free concert on Copacabana beach today, turning its vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor. It comes after Rio de Janeiro spent the last few days readying itself for the historic performance by the Queen of Pop.\n\nRio's City Hall has said some 1.5 million spectators are anticipated, more than 10 times more than Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 in Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website has been hyping the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nIt will be the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective which kicked off in October in London.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz has been palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage that's in front of her hotel, they danced on the sand.\n\nBy about noon Saturday, hundreds of fans had gathered in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you\".\n\nFlags with Madonna printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area was teeming with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who was supporting a gold-coloured cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers have been spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show is set to start at 9.45 pm local time.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert will inject 293 million Brazilian reals (NZ$96 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity is expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. And Rio's international airport forecast an extra 170 flights from May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Ceara state -- approximately 2500 km from Rio.\n\n\"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of a upturned bottle cap resembling a crown. Heineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement, with bars and restaurants reportedly preparing \"like a virgin\" cocktails, named for her 1984 hit. A shop in the downtown neighbourhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear.\n\nOrganisation of the mega-event will be similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for the world-famous fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there has been some concern such problems may occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio state's security plan includes the presence of 3200 military personnel and 1500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy carried out inspections of vessels that wish to position themselves at sea to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records.\n\nMany spectators had come to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police cited by Folha de Sao Paulo newspaper at the time.", "source": {"uri": "1news.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "1 News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@1news.co.nz", "name": {"uri": "8114087424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "15:54:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T15:54:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T15:53:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.news24.com/life/arts-and-entertainment/music/from-pop-icon-to-rios-queen-madonna-wraps-celebration-tour-with-historic-beach-bash-in-brazil-20240506", "title": "From pop icon to Rio's queen: Madonna wraps Celebration Tour with historic beach bash in Brazil | Life", "body": "Billed as a \"historic\" show, it blended music and dance with cabaret.\n\nPop idol Madonna gave it all in Rio de Janeiro as she looked back on her four-decade career in a historic show before throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana Beach on Saturday night.\n\nThe 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel shortly after 22:30 to a massive stage for one of the most important shows of her career.\n\nDressed all in black, Madonna broke into her hit Nothing Really Matters at the start of a burst of brute energy.\n\n\"Rio, here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" she said at the start of a performance that brought the giddy Brazilian audience to its feet.\n\nThe show marked the final stop on her Celebration Tour, noting her 40 years atop pop charts, in a free event that drew an estimated 1.6 million people from across Brazil, according to the city tourism office.\n\nBilled as a \"historic\" show, it blended music and dance with cabaret.\n\nMadonna showcased her versatility with dozens of set and costume changes, spectacular lights and many giant screens along the beach.\n\nShe went from being dressed as a schoolgirl in a miniskirt to an irreverent Christian in a black cape while luminous crosses circled around her during Like a Prayer, a song that cost her excommunication from the Catholic Church.\n\n'Live To Tell'\n\nMadonna was joined on stage during the performance of her hit Vogue by Brazilian singer Anitta, who is known for taking Carioca funk - the soundtrack of Rio's favelas - to the rest of the world.\n\nWith Live To Tell, she paid tribute to AIDS victims, including Freddie Mercury and the legendary Brazilian musician Cazuza.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands jostled to get a view of the stage. Boats bobbed in the water offshore, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder was Madonna's phrase: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a transgender woman standing near the huge stage that was twice the size of any other used on the tour.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimise the usual mass robberies.\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection in June last year.\n\nALSO READ | Madonna opens up about being in a coma and her 'near-death' experience\n\nMadonna has released an album every two or three years since the 1984 release of Like a Virgin.\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, such as when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video Like a Prayer, which was seen as blasphemous.\n\n'Oi, Rio!'\n\nMadonna's concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million production cost.\n\nAuthorities expected it would pump a far larger sum - 293 million reales or $57 million - into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighbourhood were billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nHundreds of her fans swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace since her arrival on Monday.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colourful balaclava.\n\nThe response on Saturday night from more than a million voices: \"Oi, Queen Madonna!\"", "source": {"uri": "8112443530", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "14:24:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T14:24:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T14:23:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "http://www.seychellesnewsagency.com/articles/20511/Madonna+wows+Rio+with+%27Celebration+Tour%27+finale", "title": "Madonna wows Rio with 'Celebration Tour' finale", "body": "Pop idol Madonna gave it all in Rio de Janeiro as she looked back on her four-decade career in a historic show before throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana beach on Saturday night.\n\nThe 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel shortly after 10:30 pm (0130 GMT Sunday) to a massive stage for one of the most important shows of her career.\n\nDressed all in black, Madonna broke into her hit \"Nothing Really Matters\" at the start of a burst of brute energy.\n\n\"Rio, here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" she said at the start of a performance that brought the giddy Brazilian audience to its feet.\n\nThe show marked the final stop on her \"Celebration Tour\" noting her 40 years atop pop charts, in a free event that was estimated to draw upward of 1.5 million fans from across Brazil.\n\nBilled as a \"historic\" show, it blended music and dance with cabaret.\n\nMadonna showcased her versatility with dozens of set and costume changes, spectacular lights and many giant screens along the beach.\n\nShe went from being dressed as a schoolgirl in a miniskirt to an irreverent Christian in a black cape while luminous crosses circled around her during \"Like a Prayer,\" a song that cost her excommunication from the Catholic Church.\n\n- 'Live To Tell' -\n\nMadonna was joined on stage during the performance of her hit \"Vogue\" by Brazilian singer Anitta, who is known for taking Carioca funk -- the soundtrack of Rio's favelas -- to the rest of the world.\n\nWith \"Live To Tell\", she paid tribute to AIDS victims, including Freddie Mercury and the legendary Brazilian musician Cazuza.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands jostled to get a view of the stage. Boats bobbed in the water offshore, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder was Madonna's phrase: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a transgender woman, standing near the huge stage that was twice the size of any other used on the tour.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimize the usual mass robberies.\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection in June last year.\n\nMadonna has released an album every two or three years since the 1984 release of \"Like a Virgin.\"\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, such as when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video \"Like a Prayer,\" which was seen as blasphemous.\n\n- 'Oi, Rio!' -\n\nMadonna's concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million production cost.\n\nAuthorities expected it would pump a far larger sum -- 293 million reales, or $57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood were billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nHundreds of her fans swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace since her arrival on Monday.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.", "source": {"uri": "seychellesnewsagency.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Seychelles News {"uri": "8111774520", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:28:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:28:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:26:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/madonna-performing-biggest-concert-ever-on-rio-de-janeiros-copacabana-beach/DBVFNJR7JBEMJESYYLZW5PWCGI/", "title": "Rio de Janeiro set for biggest Madonna concert ever", "body": "Madonna is giving a free concert on Copacabana Beach, turning its vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor. It comes after Rio de Janeiro spent the last few days readying itself for the historic performance by the \"Queen of Pop\".\n\nRio's City Hall has said some 1.5 million spectators are anticipated, more than 10 times more than Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 in Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website has been hyping the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nIt will be the last show of the Celebration Tour, her first retrospective which kicked off in October in London.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz has been palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage that's in front of her hotel, they danced on the sand.\n\nHundreds of fans gathered in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you\".\n\nFlags with 'Madonna' printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved footpath pattern hung from balconies. The area was teeming with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who was supporting a gold-coloured cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers have been spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show was set to start at 9.45pm local time.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert will inject 293 million reals ($96.1m) into the local economy. Hotel capacity is expected to reach 98 per cent in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. And Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights from May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Ceara state -- approximately 2500km from Rio.\n\n\"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of a upturned bottle cap resembling a crown. Heineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement, with bars and restaurants reportedly preparing \"Like a Virgin\" cocktails, named for her 1984 hit. A shop in the downtown neighbourhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear.\n\nOrganisation of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for the world-famous fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there has been some concern such problems may occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio state's security plan included the presence of 3200 military personnel and 1500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's Navy carried out inspections of vessels that wish to position themselves at sea to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana Beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than four million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records. Many spectators had come to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police cited by Folha de Sao Paulo newspaper at the time.", "source": {"uri": "nzherald.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "NZ Herald"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Yakima", "body": "Pop idol Madonna gave it all in Rio de Janeiro as she looked back on her four-decade career in a historic show before throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana beach on Saturday night.\n\nThe 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel shortly after 10:30 pm (0130 GMT Sunday) to a massive stage for one of the most important shows of her career.\n\nDressed all in black, Madonna broke into her hit \"Nothing Really Matters\" at the start of a burst of brute energy.\n\n\"Rio, here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" she said at the start of a performance that brought the giddy Brazilian audience to its feet.\n\nThe show marked the final stop on her \"Celebration Tour\" noting her 40 years atop pop charts, in a free event that was estimated to draw upward of 1.5 million fans from across Brazil.\n\nBilled as a \"historic\" show, it blended music and dance with cabaret.\n\nMadonna showcased her versatility with dozens of set and costume changes, spectacular lights and many giant screens along the beach.\n\nShe went from being dressed as a schoolgirl in a miniskirt to an irreverent Christian in a black cape while luminous crosses circled around her during \"Like a Prayer,\" a song that cost her excommunication from the Catholic Church.\n\n- 'Live To Tell' -\n\nMadonna was joined on stage during the performance of her hit \"Vogue\" by Brazilian singer Anitta, who is known for taking Carioca funk -- the soundtrack of Rio's favelas -- to the rest of the world.\n\nWith \"Live To Tell\", she paid tribute to AIDS victims, including Freddie Mercury and the legendary Brazilian musician Cazuza.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands jostled to get a view of the stage. Boats bobbed in the water offshore, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder was Madonna's phrase: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a transgender woman, standing near the huge stage that was twice the size of any other used on the tour.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimize the usual mass robberies.\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection in June last year.\n\nMadonna has released an album every two or three years since the 1984 release of \"Like a Virgin.\"\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, such as when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video \"Like a Prayer,\" which was seen as blasphemous.\n\n- 'Oi, Rio!' -\n\nMadonna's concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million production cost.\n\nAuthorities expected it would pump a far larger sum -- 293 million reales, or $57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood were billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nHundreds of her fans swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace since her arrival on Monday.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.\n\nThat scene was repeated on Friday.\n\n\"Oi, Rio!\" she called out in Portuguese to fans.\n\nThe response on Saturday night from more than a million voices: \"Oi, Queen Madonna!\"\n\nll/app/sn/pbt\n\nFOX41 Yakima\u00a9FOX11 TriCities\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox41yakima.com", {"uri": "8111992406", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "07:07:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T07:07:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T07:06:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/entertainment/2024/05/05/madonnas-free-copacabana-beach-concert-attracts-estimated-crowd-of-16m/", "title": "Madonna's free Copacabana beach concert attracts estimated crowd of 1.6m", "body": "Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach on Saturday night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with many of her fans.\n\nIt was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London.\n\nThe \"Queen of Pop\" began the show with her 1998 hit Nothing Really Matters.\n\nHuge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd pressed against the barriers. Others looked on from brightly lighted apartments and hotels lining the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead.\n\nPointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nAn estimated 1.6 million people attended the gig, more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987.\n\nMadonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. They danced on the sand during the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel.\n\nBy midday on Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. {"uri": "8112053127", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "08:09:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T08:09:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T08:08:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.bssnews.net/news/187218", "title": "Madonna wows Rio with 'Celebration Tour' finale | News", "body": "PM opens AFIP, Senaprangan Bhabans in Dhaka Cantonment Israel army says five Palestinians killed in West Bank raid Hamas official says group will not accept truce that does not end Gaza war BCL expresses solidarity with demand of independent Palestinian state Bangladesh to witness heavy rainfall with thunderstorm from May 6: BMD\n\nRIO DE JANEIRO, May 5, 2024 (BSS/AFP) - Pop idol Madonna gave it all in Rio\n\nde Janeiro as she looked back on her four-decade career in a historic show\n\nbefore throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana beach on\n\nSaturday night.\n\nThe 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana\n\nPalace hotel shortly after 10:30 pm (0130 GMT Sunday) to a massive stage for\n\none of the most important shows of her career.\n\nDressed all in black, Madonna broke into her hit \"Nothing Really Matters\" at\n\nthe start of a burst of brute energy.\n\n\"Rio, here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" she said at the\n\nstart of a performance that brought the giddy Brazilian audience to its feet.\n\nThe show marked the final stop on her \"Celebration Tour\" noting her 40 years\n\natop pop charts, in a free event that was estimated to draw upward of 1.5\n\nmillion fans from across Brazil.\n\nBilled as a \"historic\" show, it blended music and dance with cabaret.\n\nMadonna showcased her versatility with dozens of set and costume changes,\n\nspectacular lights and many giant screens along the beach.\n\nShe went from being dressed as a schoolgirl in a miniskirt to an irreverent\n\nChristian in a black cape while luminous crosses circled around her during\n\n\"Like a Prayer,\" a song that cost her excommunication from the Catholic\n\nChurch.\n\n- 'Live To Tell' -\n\nMadonna was joined on stage during the performance of her hit \"Vogue\" by\n\nBrazilian singer Anitta, who is known for taking Carioca funk -- the\n\nsoundtrack of Rio's favelas -- to the rest of the world.\n\nWith \"Live To Tell\", she paid tribute to AIDS victims, including Freddie\n\nMercury and the legendary Brazilian musician Cazuza.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands\n\njostled to get a view of the stage. Boats bobbed in the water offshore,\n\nletting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\"\n\n29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder was\n\nMadonna's phrase: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and\n\nchange my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a transgender woman,\n\nstanding near the huge stage that was twice the size of any other used on the\n\ntour.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimize the usual mass robberies.\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert\n\nprovided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the\n\nsinger suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection in June last year.\n\nMadonna has released an album every two or three years since the 1984 release\n\nof \"Like a Virgin.\"\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-\n\nprovocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, such as when she\n\nkissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church,\n\nwith Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989\n\nvideo \"Like a Prayer,\" which was seen as blasphemous.\n\n- 'Oi, Rio!' -\n\nMadonna's concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed\n\n20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million production cost.\n\nAuthorities expected it would pump a far larger sum -- 293 million reales, or\n\n$57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood were billboards, souvenirs or\n\nT-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean\n\nPaul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nHundreds of her fans swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace since her arrival\n\non Monday.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a\n\nsound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.\n\nThe response on Saturday night from more than a million {"uri": "8111881587", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "05:02:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T05:02:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T05:01:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/entertainment/2024/05/05/madonna-turns-copacabana-beach-into-massive-dance-floor-with-free-rio-concert/", "title": "Madonna turns Copacabana beach into massive dance floor with free Rio concert", "body": "Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach on Saturday night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with many of her fans.\n\nIt was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London.\n\nThe \"Queen of Pop\" began the show with her 1998 hit Nothing Really Matters.\n\nHuge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd pressed against the barriers. Others looked on from brightly lighted apartments and hotels lining the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead.\n\nPointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nRio's City Hall predicted 1.5 million spectators, more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987.\n\nMadonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. They danced on the sand during the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel.\n\nBy midday on Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying: \"Welcome, Madonna. You are the best. I love you.\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black-and-white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area teemed with street vendors, and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-coloured cone bra and a black cap.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure all attendees could hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10.37pm local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would inject 293 million reals (\u00a346 million) into the local economy.\n\nHotel capacity was expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association.\n\nFans from Brazil, Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement.\n\nRio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights for the first week of May from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna; who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state -- approximately 1,555 miles from Rio.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8114172140", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "16:57:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T16:57:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T16:57:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://remezcla.com/music/heres-what-happened-at-madonnas-historic-concert-in-brazil/", "title": "Here's What Happened at Madonna's Historic Concert in Brazil", "body": "Madonna closed out her Celebration Tour in an epic way in Brazil. On Saturday (May 4), the queen of pop made history with her concert in Rio de Janeiro, which included the country's biggest stars, and broke attendance records.\n\nLast month, Madonna announced that she would end her Celebration Tour with a final stop in Rio de Janeiro, and ultimately made history with her free concert at Copacabana Beach. Over 1.6 million fans came to see Madonna's concert on Saturday, which broke a record for the largest concert for a stand-alone show by any artist. The concert was also broadcast live on the Brazilian network Globo TV.\n\nWhile performing in Brazil, Madonna brought out two of the country's top artists as special guests. Brazil's premier drag pop star Pabllo Vittar joined Madonna onstage during her performance of \"Music.\" Vittar later reflected on Instagram about the experience of performing a samba-infused version of the Madonna classic. \"I love you Madonna,\" she wrote in the caption of her post.\n\nMadonna's second special guest was Brazilian superstar Anitta. She brought out the \"Envolver\" hit-maker during her performance of \"Vogue.\" Madonna and Anitta judged her dancers on the runway in the style of the queer ballroom scene. Anitta also shared words on Instagram about her time with Madonna.\n\n\"Yesterday was a historical night for my city Rio de Janeiro,\" she wrote. \"Madonna finished her tour at the Copacabana beach for more than 1 million people. Such a special time for all of us. I feel really honored you invited me to be part of this moment.
