{"uri": "8111852121", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "04:22:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T04:22:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T04:21:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.lemonde.fr/en/culture/article/2024/05/05/in-brazil-madonna-turns-copacabana-into-giant-dance-floor-with-free-concert_6670470_30.html", "title": "In Brazil, Madonna gives a giant free concert on Copacabana beach", "body": "Madonna put on a free concert on Copacabana beach Saturday night, May 4, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with a multitude of her fans. It was the last show of The Celebration Tour, her first retrospective, which kicked off in October in London.\n\nThe \"Queen of Pop\" began the show with her 1998 hit Nothing Really Matters. Huge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd, pressed up against the barriers. Others looked on from brightly lighted apartments and hotels lining the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna told the crowd. Pointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\" Rio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nRio's City Hall predicted 1.5 million spectators, more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest ever in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand. By midday Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you.\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area teemedwith street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10:37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would inject 293 million reals ($57 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown.\n\nHeineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement. Bars and restaurants prepared \"Like a Virgin\" cocktails, named for her 1984 hit. A shop in the downtown neighborhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs, and even underwear.\n\nOrganization of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio State's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on standby. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records. Many of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time.", "source": {"uri": "lemonde.fr", "dataType": "news", "title": "Le Monde.fr"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8111831892", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:55:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:55:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:54:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/madonna-kicks-off-huge-show-before-giddy-fans-in-rio/article_d4396087-c743-5caf-b2c9-816fd966bad6.html", "title": "Madonna kicks off huge show before giddy fans in Rio", "body": "Aerial view shows the crowd before US pop star Madonna's free concert in Rio de Janeiro\n\nDressed all in black, pop idol Madonna broke into her hit \"Nothing Really Matters\" Saturday night before throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana beach in Rio.\n\nShortly after 10:30 pm (0130 GMT Sunday), the 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel to a massive stage for one of the most important shows of her career.\n\nIt marked the final stop on her \"Celebration Tour\" noting her 40 years atop pop charts, in a free event expected to draw upward of 1.5 million fans from across Brazil.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands jostled to get a view of the stage. Huge screens dotted the venue. Offshore, boats bobbed in the water, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder is a phrase from the pop idol: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a trans woman, standing near the huge stage -- twice the size of any used previously on the tour.\n\nHours before the show, fans were already dancing to Madonna's songs blasting from the speakers on stage.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimize the usual mass robberies.\n\n- A 'virgin' and a 'material girl' -\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer in June suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection.\n\nSince the 1984 release of \"Like a Virgin,\" Madonna has released an album every two or three years.\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, like when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video \"Like a Prayer,\" seen as blasphemous.\n\nIn Rio, the singer was expected to, over a span of two hours, portray all the Madonnas: the \"Material Girl,\" the bride, the rebellious Catholic, the virgin, the cowgirl, and others.\n\n- 'Oi, Rio!' -\n\nThe concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million cost of the production.\n\nAuthorities say the concert should pump a far larger sum -- 293 million reales, or $57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood are billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nSince the singer's arrival in Rio on Monday, hundreds of her fans have swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.\n\nThat scene was repeated on Friday.\n\n\"Oi, Rio!\" she called out in Portuguese to fans.\n\nThe response on Saturday night from more than a million voices: \"Oi, Queen Madonna!\"\n\nll/app/llu/lbc/bbk/tjj/dhw", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, {"uri": "8113117267", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "04:22:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T04:22:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T04:19:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.wionews.com/entertainment/hollywood/news-madonnas-free-concert-in-rio-pulls-in-massive-crowds-16-million-attended-the-show-718332", "title": "Madonna's free concert in Rio pulls in massive crowds, 1.6 million attended the show", "body": "It was a full house at Madonna's concert in Rio as massive crowds attended the free show.\n\nIt felt like the whole city emerged as Madonna put on a free concert in Rio de Janeiro. It is reported that more than 1.6 million people turned up for the concert which took place at Brazil's famous Copacabana beach. Performing in front of huge crowds that turned up for the music and for a glimpse of the pop icon, Madonna gave a stellar show to all.\n\nAs she danced and sang in her element, Madonna said, \"Rio, here we are in the most beautiful place in the world.\"\n\nMadonna's concert in Rio is part of her Celebration Tour. She's celebrating 40 years in music.\n\nMadonna teased fans with a preview before the concert. Some seven hours before the show, the singer posted on Instagram and wrote, \"Are you ready?\"\n\nIt was everything that a Madonna fan would want - there was exemplary music, dance, a lot of set and costume changes and beautiful light displays - that set the mood for the night.\n\nBefore Madonna arrived for the show, crowds of fans were seen dancing to Madonna's songs played from the speakers on the stage. This was hours before her concert began and she made an appearance.\n\nMadonna sang some of her greatest hits, including \"Nothing Really Matters\", \"Like a Prayer\" and \"Vogue\". She was also joined on stage at one point by Brazilian singer Anitta.\n\nAlso read: Ouch! {"uri": "8112204837", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "10:33:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T10:33:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T10:32:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.nationthailand.com/life/entertainment/40037797", "title": "Madonna's biggest-ever concert draws 1.6 million to Copacabana beach", "body": "In recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. During the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel, they danced on the sand.\n\nBy midday Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying, \"Welcome Madonna you are the best I love you.\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black and white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area was packed with street vendors and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-colored cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure that all attendees can hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10:37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would vinject 293 million reals ($57 million) into the local economy. Hotel capacity was expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Fans hailing from across Brazil and even Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights during May 1-6, from 27 destinations, City Hall said in a statement.\n\n\"It's a unique opportunity to see Madonna, who knows if she'll ever come back,\" said Alessandro Augusto, 53, who flew in from Brazil's Ceara state -- approximately 2,500 kilometers (1,555 miles) from Rio.\n\n\"Welcome Queen!\" read Heineken ads plastered around the city, the lettering above an image of an upturned bottle cap resembling a crown.\n\nHeineken wasn't the only company seeking to profit from the excitement. Bars and restaurants prepared \"Like a Virgin\" cocktails. A shop in the downtown neighborhood famed for selling Carnival attire completely reinvented itself, stocking its shelves with Madonna-themed costumes, fans, fanny packs and even underwear.\n\nOrganization of the mega-event was similar to New Year's Eve, when millions of people gather on Copacabana for its fireworks display, local authorities said. That annual event often produces widespread thefts and muggings, and there was some concern such problems might occur at Madonna's show.\n\nRio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nA number of huge concerts have taken place on Copacabana beach before, including a 1994 New Year's Eve show by Rod Stewart that drew more than 4 million fans and was the biggest free rock concert in history, according to Guinness World Records. Many of those spectators also came to see Rio's fireworks show, though, so a more fitting comparison might be to the Rolling Stones in 2006, which saw 1.2 million people crowd onto the sand, according to Rio's military police, the newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo reported at the time.\n\nAna Beatriz Soares, a fan who was at Copacabana on Saturday, said Madonna has made her mark across the decades.\n\n\"Madonna had to run so that today's pop artists could walk. That's why she's important, because she serves as an inspiration for today's pop divas,\" Soares said.\n\n\"And that's 40 years ago. Not 40 days, 40 months. {"uri": "8111899605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "05:23:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T05:23:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T05:22:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.bssnews.net/news/187193", "title": "Giddy Rio braces for huge Madonna show on Copacabana beach | News", "body": "RIO DE JANEIRO, May 5, 2024 (BSS/AFP) - Rio de Janeiro was brimming with excitement Saturday ahead of pop queen Madonna's highly anticipated free concert on famed Copacabana beach, with 1.5 million enthusiastic fans expected to turn out.\n\n\"Are you ready?\" the 65-year-old American superstar posted on her Instagram account seven hours before the show celebrating her 40-year career as a musical, style and cultural icon.\n\nThe final stop of \"The Celebration Tour\" follows weeks of intense preparation, involving thousands of people and generating a fever pitch of excitement in the iconic Brazilian city, with talk of little else.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder is a phrase from the pop idol: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a trans woman, standing near the huge stage -- twice the size of any used previously on the tour -- built on the beach.\n\nAt nightfall, the \"world's largest dance floor\" will light up, with a succession of DJs performing.\n\nHours before the show, throngs of fans were already dancing to Madonna's songs blasting from speakers on the stage.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner in an attempt to minimize the usual mass robberies.\n\nIf things stick to schedule, at 9:50 pm (00H50 GMT Sunday), the pop queen will stride onto an elevated walkway from the emblematic Copacabana Palace hotel, where she is staying, to the stage for one of the most important performances of her career.\n\n- A 'virgin' and a mother -\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert will provide a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer in June suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection.\n\nSince the 1984 release of \"Like a Virgin,\" Madonna has released an album every two or three years.\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, like when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video \"Like a Prayer,\" seen as blasphemous.\n\nIn Rio, the singer will, over a span of two hours, portray ALL the Madonnas: the \"Material Girl,\" the bride, the rebellious Catholic, the virgin, the cowgirl, and others.\n\nShe will affirm her motherhood as well: four of her six children will share the stage with her.\n\n- 'Oi, Rio!' -\n\nTwo rehearsals on the eve of the concert, held in view of beachgoers, offered some clues as to what can be expected.\n\nMadonna sang \"Nothing Really Matters\" and \"Burning Up,\" as well as \"Live to Tell,\" in homage to AIDS victims.\n\nThe singer Pabllo Vittar, backed by a group of young drummers, also took part in the rehearsals, as did funk queen Anitta, who in 2020 recorded \"Faz Gostoso\" with Madonna.\n\nThe audience can also expect to hear hits such as \"Material Girl,\" \"Papa Don't Preach,\" \"La Isla Bonita\" and more than 20 other songs.\n\nThe concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million cost of the production.\n\nAuthorities say the concert should pump a far larger sum -- 293 million reales, or $57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood are billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nSince the singer's arrival in Rio on Monday, hundreds of her fans have swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.\n\nThe response will come Saturday night from more than a million voices: \"Oi, Queen Madonna!\"", "source": {"uri": "bssnews.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bangladesh Sangbad Sangstha (BSS)"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Others looked on from brightly lighted apartments and hotels lining the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna told the crowd.\n\nPointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nAn estimated 1.6 million people attended the gig, more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987.\n\nMadonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. {"uri": "8114373848", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "19:54:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T19:54:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T19:54:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://uinterview.com/news/1-6-million-fans-swarm-to-free-madonna-concert-in-rio-de-janeiro/", "title": "1.6 Million Fans Swarm To Free Madonna Concert In Rio De Janeiro - uInterview", "body": "Madonna's free concert on Saturday in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, drew 1.6 million fans to its famed Copacabana Beach. The concert marked the final show of Madonna's Celebration Tour, which started in October.\n\nThe 65-year-old pop singer's last concert included her classic hits like \"Like A Virgin\" and \"Hung Up.\" Fans packed the area and pushed against barriers, cheering on. House parties in apartments and hotels started to join the festivities while others watched from boats in the bay.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna said on stage. \"This place is magic.\"\n\nAccording to Madonna's official website, the Brazil show was the biggest of her four-decade career. It ten-fold exceeded the record attendance of 130,000 fans at her 1987 show at Paris' Parc dex Sceaux.\n\nKey moments from the show included Brazilian artists Anitta and Pabllo Vittar joining the singer on stage. During Madonna's performance of \"Live to Tell,\" she paid tribute to \"all the bright lights\" lost to AIDS, with black-and-white photos of those who lost their lives flashing behind her.\n\nMadonna was given warm welcomes from fans and companies like Heineken, who put out ads that said, \"Welcome Queen!\" Fans crowded around the Copacabana Palace Hotel, where Madonna stayed, to see the star.\n\nThe show started 50 minutes later, at 10:37 p.m. local time. Madonna has had issues with scheduling in the past. In January, two fans filed a lawsuit against the singer for starting her New York concert two hours late. Regardless, the free Brazil concert received a positive reception.\n\nLeave a comment Cancel reply Read more about: Madonna The Celebration Tour", "source": {"uri": "uinterview.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8111810738", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:23:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:23:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:22:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/madonna-kicks-off-huge-show-before-giddy-fans-in-rio/article_00f5f6e0-bcae-540a-991a-ba8cd94bb912.html", "title": "Madonna kicks off huge show before giddy fans in Rio", "body": "Aerial view shows the crowd before US pop star Madonna's free concert in Rio de Janeiro\n\nDressed all in black, pop idol Madonna broke into her hit \"Nothing Really Matters\" Saturday night before throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana beach in Rio.\n\nShortly after 10:30 pm (0130 GMT Sunday), the 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel to a massive stage for one of the most important shows of her career.\n\nIt marked the final stop on her \"Celebration Tour\" noting her 40 years atop pop charts, in a free event expected to draw upward of 1.5 million fans from across Brazil.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands jostled to get a view of the stage. Huge screens dotted the venue. Offshore, boats bobbed in the water, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder is a phrase from the pop idol: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a trans woman, standing near the huge stage -- twice the size of any used previously on the tour.\n\nHours before the show, fans were already dancing to Madonna's songs blasting from the speakers on stage.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimize the usual mass robberies.\n\n- A 'virgin' and a 'material girl' -\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer in June suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection.\n\nSince the 1984 release of \"Like a Virgin,\" Madonna has released an album every two or three years.\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, like when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nMore from this section 87 Days: The Search for Stephanie Parze - premieres tonight at 930pm Moose hide tanning camp offers all ages age-old techniques Omar Abdullah's Nomination, Heatwave in Lok Sabha Elections, PM Modi's Jibe & More | Oneindia News\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video \"Like a Prayer,\" seen as blasphemous.\n\nIn Rio, the singer was expected to, over a span of two hours, portray all the Madonnas: the \"Material Girl,\" the bride, the rebellious Catholic, the virgin, the cowgirl, and others.\n\n- 'Oi, Rio!' -\n\nThe concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million cost of the production.\n\nAuthorities say the concert should pump a far larger sum -- 293 million reales, or $57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood are billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nSince the singer's arrival in Rio on Monday, hundreds of her fans have swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.\n\nThat scene was repeated on Friday.\n\n\"Oi, Rio!\" she called out in Portuguese to fans.\n\nThe response on Saturday night from more than a million voices: \"Oi, Queen Madonna!\"\n\nll/app/llu/lbc/bbk/tjj/dhw", {"uri": "8114225732", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:40:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:40:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T17:40:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.digitalmusicnews.com/2024/05/06/madonna-concert-rio-de-janeiro-record/", "title": "Madonna's Free Rio Concert Draws 1.6 Million Fans", "body": "Save\n\nPhoto Credit: Guilherme Romer\n\nMadonna concluded her 'Celebration Tour' in Rio de Janeiro with a free concert -- drawing in a crowd of more than 1.6 million people to Copacabana beach. It's the largest audience on record to watch a single-artist perform.\n\nThe legendary singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel at around 10:30 pm to kick things off on the massive stage. She wore all black and started the show with her hit, \"Nothing Really Matters.\" Millions of Brazilians packed the beach to see her, with her starting the concert calling Rio \"the most beautiful place in the world.\"\n\nMadonna performed dozens of songs in her set which featured several costume changes, lighting, and giant screens for the massive crowd to see her. Video from social media panning across the crowd showcases just how large the event really was. Madonna was joined on stage during her performance of \"Vogue\" by Brazilian singer Anitta. Later she moved on to \"Live to Tell,\" paying homage to AIDS victims including Freddie Mercury and Brazilian musician Cazuza.\n\nThe massive Madonna concert is estimated to provide a huge economic boon to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4M) toward the $12M show production costs.\n\nAccording to local authorities, they expect to see around 293 million reales ($57M) pumped back into the local economy thanks to this massive event. Brazil loves Madonna, with every corner of the Copacabana neighborhood littered with billboards, souvenirs, and t-shirts featuring images of the pop star.\n\nThe concert was a celebration of Madonna over the decades, made especially potent by the health scare the pop star had in June 2023. She was found unconscious and rushed to a hospital, where she received treatment for a serious bacterial infection. After more than 80 shows performed across Europe and North America -- Madonna put the capstone on her successful 'Celebration Tour' with an unforgettable night in Rio.\n\nShare on:\n\nFacebook Twitter {"uri": "8111828719", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:50:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:50:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:50:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.malaymail.com/news/showbiz/2024/05/05/madonna-kicks-off-huge-show-before-giddy-fans-in-rios-copacabana-beach/132508", "title": "Madonna kicks off huge show before giddy fans in Rio's Copacabana beach", "body": "Join us on our WhatsApp Channel, follow us on Instagram, and receive browser alerts for the latest news you need to know.\n\nRIO DE JANEIRO, May 5 -- Dressed all in black, pop idol Madonna broke into her hit Nothing Really Matters last night before throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana beach in Rio.\n\nShortly after 10.30pm (9.30am Sunday Malaysian time), the 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel to a massive stage for one of the most important shows of her career.\n\nIt marked the final stop on her Celebration Tour noting her 40 years atop pop charts, in a free event expected to draw upward of 1.5 million fans from across Brazil.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands jostled to get a view of the stage. Huge screens dotted the venue. Offshore, boats bobbed in the water, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder is a phrase from the pop idol: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a trans woman, standing near the huge stage -- twice the size of any used previously on the tour -- built on the beach.\n\nAt nightfall, the \"world's largest dance floor\" will light up, with a succession of DJs performing.\n\nHours before the show, throngs of fans were already dancing to Madonna's songs blasting from speakers on the stage.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner in an attempt to minimise the usual mass robberies.\n\nA 'virgin' and a mother\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert will provide a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer in June suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection.\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, like when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video Like a Prayer, seen as blasphemous.\n\nIn Rio, the singer will, over a span of two hours, portray ALL the Madonnas: the Material Girl, the bride, the rebellious Catholic, the virgin, the cowgirl, and others.\n\nShe will affirm her motherhood as well: four of her six children will share the stage with her.\n\n'Oi, Rio!'\n\nTwo rehearsals on the eve of the concert, held in view of beachgoers, offered some clues as to what can be expected.\n\nMadonna sang Nothing Really Matters and Burning Up, as well as Live to Tell, in homage to AIDS victims.\n\nThe singer Pabllo Vittar, backed by a group of young drummers, also took part in the rehearsals, as did funk queen Anitta, who in 2020 recorded Faz Gostoso with Madonna.\n\nThe audience can also expect to hear hits such as Material Girl, Papa Don't Preach, La Isla Bonita and more than 20 other songs.\n\nThe concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales (RM18.7 million) toward the US$12 million (RM56.9 million) cost of the production.\n\nAuthorities say the concert should pump a far larger sum -- 293 million reales, or US$57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighbourhood are billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nSince the singer's arrival in Rio on Monday, hundreds of her fans have swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colourful balaclava.\n\nThe response on Saturday night from more than a million voices: \"Oi, Queen Madonna!\" -- AFP", "source": {"uri": "malaymail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Malay Mail"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madonna", "type": Huge screens dotted the venue. Offshore, boats bobbed in the water, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told Agence France-Presse. Tattooed on her shoulder is a phrase from the pop idol: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a trans woman, standing near the huge stage -- twice the size of any used previously on the tour.\n\nHours before the show, fans were already dancing to Madonna's songs blasting from the speakers on stage.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimize the usual mass robberies.\n\nA 'virgin' and a 'material girl'\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer in June suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection.\n\nSince the 1984 release of \"Like a Virgin,\" Madonna has released an album every two or three years.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, like when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video \"Like a Prayer,\" seen as blasphemous.\n\nIn Rio, the singer was expected to, over a span of two hours, portray all the Madonnas: the \"Material Girl,\" the bride, the rebellious Catholic, the virgin, the cowgirl, and others.\n\n'Oi, Rio!'\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million cost of the production.\n\nAuthorities say the concert should pump a far larger sum -- 293 million reales, or $57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood are billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nSince the singer's arrival in Rio on Monday, hundreds of her fans have swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.\n\nThat scene was repeated on Friday.\n\n\"Oi, Rio!\" she {"uri": "2024-05-346202872", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "08:27:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T08:27:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T01:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/entertainment/music/music-news/madonna-wraps-up-celebration-tour-performing-to-history-making-16-million-fans-at-rios-copacabana-beach/a1707316482.html", "title": "Madonna wraps up Celebration tour, performing to history-making 1.6 million fans at Rio's Copacabana beach", "body": "Madonna performed her biggest ever show at the weekend, closing her Celebration world tour in front of 1.6 million fans at a free gig on Rio's Copacabana beach.\n\nDespite starting 50 minutes late, Madonna packed more than 20 songs from 15 albums into her show and was joined on stage by Latin star Anitta to perform Vogue.\n\nThe 65-year-old began the tour in London last October and has been performing an eclectic mix of her catalogue on dates around the world.\n\nThe Copacabana show dwarfed her previous record crowd of 130,000 at Paris's Parc des Sceaux in 1987.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna told the crowd.\n\nPointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance. Madonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest in her four-decade career.\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star.\n\nBy midday on Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying: \"Welcome, Madonna. You are the best. I love you.\"\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black-and-white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies.\n\nThe area teemed with street vendors, and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun. Eighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure all attendees could hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10.37pm local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would inject 293 million reals (\u20ac56m) into the local economy.\n\nHotel capacity was expected to reach 98pc in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association. Rio's international airport had forecast an extra 170 flights for the first week of May from 27 destinations. {"uri": "8111874310", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "04:51:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T04:51:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T04:51:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://gulfnews.com/entertainment/music/madonna-kicks-off-huge-show-before-giddy-fans-in-rio-1.1714884421612", "title": "Madonna kicks off huge show before giddy fans in Rio", "body": "Rio De Janeiro: Dressed all in black, pop idol Madonna broke into her hit \"Nothing Really Matters\" Saturday night before throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana beach in Rio.\n\nShortly after 10:30 pm (0130 GMT Sunday), the 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel to a massive stage for one of the most important shows of her career.\n\nGet exclusive content with Gulf News WhatsApp channel\n\nIt marked the final stop on her \"Celebration Tour\" noting her 40 years atop pop charts, in a free event expected to draw upward of 1.5 million fans from across Brazil.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands jostled to get a view of the stage. Huge screens dotted the venue. Offshore, boats bobbed in the water, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder is a phrase from the pop idol: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a trans woman, standing near the huge stage - twice the size of any used previously on the tour.\n\nHours before the show, fans were already dancing to Madonna's songs blasting from the speakers on stage.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimise the usual mass robberies.\n\nA 'virgin' and a 'material girl'\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer in June suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection.\n\nSince the 1984 release of \"Like a Virgin,\" Madonna has released an album every two or three years.\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, like when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video \"Like a Prayer,\" seen as blasphemous.\n\nIn Rio, the singer was expected to, over a span of two hours, portray all the Madonnas: the \"Material Girl,\" the bride, the rebellious Catholic, the virgin, the cowgirl, and others.\n\n'Oi, Rio!'\n\nThe concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million cost of the production.\n\nAuthorities say the concert should pump a far larger sum - 293 million reales, or $57 million - into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood are billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nSince the singer's arrival in Rio on Monday, hundreds of her fans have swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.\n\nThat scene was repeated on Friday.\n\n\"Oi, Rio!\" she called out in Portuguese to fans.\n\nThe response {"uri": "8111816612", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:32:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:32:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:31:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.fox41yakima.com/madonna-kicks-off-huge-show-before-giddy-fans-in-rio/", "title": "Madonna kicks off huge show before giddy fans in Rio | Fox 11 Tri Cities Fox 41 Yakima", "body": "Dressed all in black, pop idol Madonna broke into her hit \"Nothing Really Matters\" Saturday night before throngs of joyful fans jammed onto Brazil's famed Copacabana beach in Rio.\n\nShortly after 10:30 pm (0130 GMT Sunday), the 65-year-old singer walked down an elevated bridge from the Copacabana Palace hotel to a massive stage for one of the most important shows of her career.\n\nIt marked the final stop on her \"Celebration Tour\" noting her 40 years atop pop charts, in a free event expected to draw upward of 1.5 million fans from across Brazil.\n\nUS electronic dance music master DJ Diplo opened the show as thousands jostled to get a view of the stage. Huge screens dotted the venue. Offshore, boats bobbed in the water, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder is a phrase from the pop idol: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a trans woman, standing near the huge stage -- twice the size of any used previously on the tour.\n\nHours before the show, fans were already dancing to Madonna's songs blasting from the speakers on stage.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimize the usual mass robberies.\n\n- A 'virgin' and a 'material girl' -\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer in June suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection.\n\nSince the 1984 release of \"Like a Virgin,\" Madonna has released an album every two or three years.\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, like when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video \"Like a Prayer,\" seen as blasphemous.\n\nIn Rio, the singer was expected to, over a span of two hours, portray all the Madonnas: the \"Material Girl,\" the bride, the rebellious Catholic, the virgin, the cowgirl, and others.\n\n- 'Oi, Rio!' -\n\nThe concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million cost of the production.\n\nAuthorities say the concert should pump a far larger sum -- 293 million reales, or $57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood are billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nSince the singer's arrival in Rio on Monday, hundreds of her fans have swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.\n\nThat scene was repeated on Friday.\n\n\"Oi, Rio!\" she called out in Portuguese to fans.\n\nThe response on Saturday night from more than a million voices: \"Oi, Queen Madonna!\"\n\nll/app/llu/lbc/bbk/tjj/dhw\n\nFOX41 Yakima\u00a9FOX11 TriCities\u00a9", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8111987323", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "07:02:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T07:02:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T07:02:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/madonna-concert-brazil-6372116-May2024/", "title": "Estimated crowd of over 1.5 million people turn out for free Madonna concert in Rio, Brazil", "body": "Rio's City Hall predicted 1.5 million spectators, more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987.\n\nMADONNA PUT ON a free concert on Copacabana beach on last night, turning Rio de Janeiro's vast stretch of sand into an enormous dance floor teeming with an estimated 1.5 million fans.\n\nIt was the last show of The Celebration Tour, which kicked off in October in London.\n\nThe \"Queen of Pop\" began the show with her 1998 hit Nothing Really Matters.\n\nHuge cheers rose from the buzzing, tightly packed crowd pressed against the barriers. Others looked on from brightly lighted apartments and hotels lining the beachfront. Helicopters and drones flew overhead.\n\nMadonna performs in the final show. Alamy Stock Photo Alamy Stock Photo\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna told the crowd.\n\nPointing out the ocean view, the mountains and the Christ the Redeemer statue overlooking the city, she added: \"This place is magic.\"\n\nRio spent the last few days readying itself for the performance.\n\nRio's City Hall predicted 1.5 million spectators, more than 10 times Madonna's record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987.\n\nMadonna's official website hyped the show as the biggest in her four-decade career.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn recent days, the buzz was palpable. Fans milled outside the stately, beachfront Copacabana Palace hotel, where Madonna is staying, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pop star. They danced on the sand during the sound check on the stage set up in front of the hotel.\n\nBy midday on Saturday, fans crowded in front of the hotel. A white-bearded man carried a sign saying: \"Welcome, Madonna. You are the best. I love you.\"\n\nA fan dances while waiting for the start of Madonna's last show of her The Celebration Tour. Alamy Stock Photo Alamy Stock Photo\n\nFlags with \"Madonna\" printed against a background of Copacabana's iconic black-and-white waved sidewalk pattern hung from balconies. The area teemed with street vendors, and concert attendees kitted out in themed T-shirts, sweating under a baking sun.\n\n\"Since Madonna arrived here, I've been coming every day with this outfit to welcome my idol, my diva, my pop queen,\" said Rosemary de Oliveira Bohrer, 69, who sported a gold-coloured cone bra and a black cap.\n\n\"It's going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana,\" said Oliveira Bohrer, a retired civil servant who lives in the area.\n\nEighteen sound towers were spread along the beach to ensure all attendees could hear the hits. Her two-hour show started at 10.37pm local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would inject 293 million reals (\u20ac53,600,000) into the local economy.\n\nHotel capacity was expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association.\n\nFans from Brazil, Argentina and France sought out Airbnbs for the weekend, the platform said in a statement.\n\nBoats sit idle off Copacabana beach as fans watch Madonna's concert. The record was previously held by The Rolling Stones, when they performed at the venue in 2006 for a then record-setting 1.5 million fans.\n\nMadonna's Celebration Tour show included performances of some of her biggest hits including \"Just Like A Prayer,\" \"Nothing Really Matters,\" and \"Music.\" The performance marked Madonna's first show in Brazil since 2012.\n\nThe songstress had a special hometown guest during the \"Vogue\" portion of the show, as Anitta surprised the audience. For the segment, the \"Bellakeo\" singer joined Madonna as a judge for the ball, as she participated with the dancers and held up a \"10\" sign.\n\nFollowing the show, Madonna took to Instagram to share a video from the stage, where she celebrates Brazil's culture by waving the flag.\n\n\"Blame it on Rio \ud83c\udde7\ud83c\uddf7 Thank You Brazil!! \ud83d\udd25\ud83c\udde7\ud83c\uddf7\ud83d\udd25\ud83c\udde7\ud83c\uddf7 \ud83d\udd25 @pabllovittar @itau @tvglobo\n\n#musicmakesthepeoplecometogether,\" she wrote.\n\nAhead of the moment, Anitta -- who just released her latest album Funk Generation -- told ET she would be missing the Met Gala, because she was showing up for Madonna.\n\n\"Not this year,\" she told ET when asked if she's going to be at the Met Gala. \"I'm gonna be in Brazil with Madonna.\"\n\nMadonna kicked-off her Celebration Tour in October 2023 at London's O2 Arena. The North American leg of the tour began in December 2023, and ran with a series of special guests including Andy Cohen, Kelly Ripa, Cardi B, Pamela Anderson and Julia Garner.\n\nThe tour was delayed, as the singer recovered from a near-fatal viral infection. Madonna got emotional during night one of the show as she reflected on the health scare.\n\n\"It's been a crazy year for me. I didn't think I was going to make it, neither did my doctors. Huge screens dotted the venue. Offshore, boats bobbed in the water, letting those onboard enjoy the show.\n\n\"I'm a mess, I haven't slept well, I've been listening to Madonna all week,\" 29-year-old sociologist Ina Odara told AFP. Tattooed on her shoulder is a phrase from the pop idol: \"All that you ever learned, try to forget.\"\n\n\"Madonna helped me leave the Catholic Church, think about many things and change my relationship with my family,\" said Odara, a trans woman, standing near the huge stage -- twice the size of any used previously on the tour.\n\nHours before the show, fans were already dancing to Madonna's songs blasting from the speakers on stage.\n\nPolice patrolled almost every corner to minimize the usual mass robberies.\n\n- A 'virgin' and a 'material girl' -\n\nAfter 80 performances across Europe and North America, the Rio concert provided a crowning touch to a tour that took on sudden urgency when the singer in June suffered a life-threatening bacterial infection.\n\nSince the 1984 release of \"Like a Virgin,\" Madonna has released an album every two or three years.\n\nHer shows, with their spectacular productions, set a high bar. But the ever-provocative Madonna has also provided unforgettable moments, like when she kissed Britney Spears at 2003's MTV Music Video Awards.\n\nHer irreverence led to a tumultuous relationship with the Catholic Church, with Pope John Paul II urging fans to boycott her over her provocative 1989 video \"Like a Prayer,\" seen as blasphemous.\n\nIn Rio, the singer was expected to, over a span of two hours, portray all the Madonnas: the \"Material Girl,\" the bride, the rebellious Catholic, the virgin, the cowgirl, and others.\n\n- 'Oi, Rio!' -\n\nThe concert should provide an economic boost to Rio, which contributed 20 million reales ($4 million) toward the $12 million cost of the production.\n\nAuthorities say the concert should pump a far larger sum -- 293 million reales, or $57 million -- into the local economy.\n\nOn every corner in the Copacabana neighborhood are billboards, souvenirs or T-shirts bearing images of Madonna or of the conical corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and made famous by the diva.\n\nSince the singer's arrival in Rio on Monday, hundreds of her fans have swarmed outside the Copacabana Palace.\n\nThe excitement spiked Thursday night when Madonna unexpectedly appeared for a sound check, her face almost completely hidden behind a colorful balaclava.\n\nThe response on Saturday night from more than a million voices: \"Oi, Queen Madonna!\"", It is going to be an unforgettable show here in Copacabana.\"\n\nIn April, Rio City Hall produced a report forecasting that the concert would inject 293 million reals ($57 million) into the local economy.\n\nLarge annual events in the city, such as the New Year's Eve celebration and the Rio Carnival, often witness widespread incidents of crime, such as thefts and muggings, and some concerns that such problems may occur at Madonna's concert have been expressed.\n\nRio state's security deployed 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on standby during the event. The record was previously held by The Rolling Stones when they performed at the venue in 2006 for a then record-setting 1.5 million fans.\n\nMadonna's Celebration Tour show included performances of some of her biggest hits, including \"Just Like A Prayer,\" \"Nothing Really Matters,\" and \"Music.\" The performance marked Madonna's first show in Brazil since 2012.\n\nThe songstress had a special hometown guest during the \"Vogue\" portion of the show as Anitta surprised the audience. The North American leg of the tour began in December 2023, and ran with a series of special guests including Andy Cohen, Kelly Ripa, Cardi B, Pamela Anderson and Julia Garner.\n\nThe tour was delayed as the singer recovered from a near-fatal viral infection. This place is magic.\"\n\nThe free show attracted huge numbers of people, who watched on giant screens positioned along the beach while others caught a glimpse of the action from boats and balconies nearby with 18 speaker towers making sure they could all hear Madonna's hits.\n\nThe 1.6 million attendance smashed Madonna's previous record of 130,000 gig-goers who attended her show at the Parc des Sceaux in Paris back in 1987.\n\nMadonna played a career-spanning set and was joined on stage by stars including Diplo, Anitta, Pabllo Vittar and Bob the Drag Queen, while the Queen of Pop delighted the audience by slipping into a Brazilian football shirt during the show.\n\nOther acts have previously attracted huge audiences with gigs on the beach with the Rolling Stones playing to 1.5 million people on their 'A Bigger Bang' tour in 2006 and Rod Stewart, who broke records with an attendance of 4.2 million on New Year's Eve in 1994.\n\nMadonna previously announced the show would be free of charge to say thank you to her loyal fans. There was also a large police presence to ensure the safety of all those in attendance.\n\nT-shirts, souvenirs and billboards with Madonna's face decked the neighbourhood as excitement built ahead of the concert.\n\nSince she burst onto the UK charts with Holiday in 1984, Madonna has scored another 71 hits, including 13 number one singles.\n\nSome, like Vogue, Like A Prayer and Ray of Light, are era-defining anthems. Others, like Live To Tell and Don't Tell Me, are beloved fan favourites.\n\nLast year, the superstar was found unconscious in her New York apartment in June and rushed to hospital, where she received treatment for a serious bacterial infection.\n\nBut she has since returned to full strength and her tour has been marked by her characteristically energetic performances.\n\nThe Rio concert was the Her two-hour show started at 10:37 p.m. local time, nearly 50 minutes behind schedule.\n\nRio state's security plan included the presence of 3,200 military personnel and 1,500 civilian police officers on stand by. In the lead-up to the concert, Brazil's navy inspected vessels that wished to position themselves offshore to follow the show.\n\nCity Hall produced a report in April estimating that the concert would inject $57 million into the local economy.\n\nHotel capacity was expected to reach 98% in Copacabana, according to Rio's hotel association.\n\nRio's international airport had forecasted an extra 170 {"uri": "8113603125", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "10:30:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T10:30:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T10:30:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://hollywoodunlocked.com/madonna-rio-concert-makes-history-crowd/", "title": "Madonna Makes History After Bringing In A Crowd Of 1.6 Million People In Rio", "body": "Madonna concluded her retrospective tour with a free concert on Copacabana Beach in Rio de Janeiro, performing in front of an estimated 1.6 million fans.\n\nThis final night marked the end of her four-decade career in pop music, with the tour having traveled around the world since last October. According to Rio's tourism agency, 1.6 million people attended the concert on the iconic city beach, which has hosted major events in the past. The Rolling Stones attracted 1.2 million fans in 2006, while Rod Stewart set the record for the largest free rock concert in history in 1994 with a crowd of 4 million (although some may have been there for the annual New Year's Eve fireworks display). Madonna's previous largest live concert audience was 130,000 fans in Paris in 1987.\n\nRELATED: Yass! Cardi B Pops Up On Stage For Madonna's Final LA Show\n\nAP News reported that Madonna kicked off the show by addressing the crowd, stating, \"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world. This place is magic.\"\n\nMadonna, the Queen of Pop, has had a long and successful career spanning over four decades. Throughout her career, she has given us some of the most iconic performances in music history. From her groundbreaking Super Bowl halftime show to her controversial MTV Video Music Awards performances, Madonna has always pushed boundaries and challenged societal norms with her electrifying stage presence.\n\nOne of Madonna's most iconic performances was her 1984 MTV Video Music Awards performance of \"Like a Virgin.\" Dressed in a wedding dress and adorned with a belt that read \"Boy Toy,\" Madonna rolled around on the stage in a provocative manner that shocked and captivated audiences. The performance catapulted her to superstardom and solidified her status as a pop culture icon.\n\nAnother unforgettable Madonna performance was her 1990 MTV Video Music Awards rendition of \"Vogue.\" Dressed in a sexy black outfit and surrounded by a troupe of dancers, Madonna channeled the glamour of old Hollywood with her sultry dance moves and flawless vocals. The performance set a new standard for live entertainment and solidified Madonna's reputation as a trendsetter in the music industry.\n\nRELATED: Madonna Says 'It's A F***ing Miracle' She's Alive 4 Months After Hospitalization: 'People Predicted I Wouldn't Make It'\n\nIn 2012, Madonna took the stage at the Super Bowl halftime show and delivered a show-stopping performance that showcased her legendary talent and charisma. From her high-energy dance routines to her powerful vocals, Madonna proved that she still had what it takes to command a global audience. PM\n\nThe Queen of Pop held a free concert at the Copacabana Beach as a \"thank you\" to her fans \"for celebrating more than four decades of music\" during her global tour\n\nMadonna promised her fans the biggest dance party in the world -- and the Queen of Pop delivered on May 4 in Rio de Janeiro.\n\nIn March the singer, 65, announced she would be performing a historic free concert at Copacabana Beach for her final Celebration Tour show, and on the night a record-breaking 1.6 million fans watched the pop superstar perform her final Celebration Tour concert.\n\nThe show made history as, though the annual New Year's Eve concerts at Copacabana Beach have drawn larger crowds, Madonna's May 4 audience was her biggest ever, and the largest ever for a stand-alone concert by any artist, a record previously held by The Rolling Stones.\n\nDuring the show, Madonna played a host of hits, including \"Like A Virgin,\" \"Like A Prayer,\" and \"Into The Groove.\"\n\nFor her performance of \"Vogue,\" the pop icon was joined on stage by Anitta, who shared her delight on her Instagram Stories.\n\n\"@madonna soooo happy for being part of this incredible moment with you,\" she wrote across a video of the two artists together on stage during the concert.\n\nSponsored by Ita\u00fa Apresenta, the concert -- her first in Brazil since 2012 -- \"will be free of charge as a thank you to her fans for celebration more than four decades of her music over the course of the epic global run of the tour,\" stated a press release.\n\nThe show took place in front of the Belmond Copacabana Palance Hotel, and entry was available on a first-come, first-serve basis.\n\nRelated: Madonna Announces Historic Free Concert in Brazil as Final Celebration Tour Show\n\nThe Material Girl kicked off her long-awaited Celebration Tour at London's O2 Arena in October with an electrifying two-hour set during which she opened up about her road back to the stage after her hospitalization last year following a serious bacterial infection.\n\n\"I didn't think I was gonna make it. Neither did my doctors. And my children always save me every time.\"\n\nLast month the singer shared a carousel of behind-the-scenes snaps of herself with her kids (David, Mercy, Stella and Estere all performed alongside mom during her run of shows) from their past few months on tour.\n\n\"On the day before our 80th show of the Celebration Tour I need to acknowledge my incredibly talented children who carried me through We take a look back, in pictures.\n\nMadonna transformed Copacabana beach in Rio de Janeiro into a sea of her fans on Saturday for the closing show of her latest world tour, The Celebration Tour, which has performed in 80 locations since October.\n\nThe final concert, announced last March, was free for everyone, and drew the largest crowd of the pop superstar's four-decade career. Riotur, Rio City Hall's tourism agency, estimated that 1.6 million people flocked to the beach to get a glimpse of Madonna.\n\nThat would make the show more than 10 times bigger than Madonna's previous record attendance of 130,000 at Paris' Parc des Sceaux in 1987.\n\nIt was a spectacular end to the singer's first stage retrospective, which featured massive hits of her career - including \"Like a Prayer,\" \"Ray of Light,\" \"Hung Up,\" and \"Holiday\" - as well as elaborate costumes and choreography.\n\nThe show began with her 1998 hit \"Nothing Really Matters\" that drew huge cheers from the tightly-packed crowd on the beach.\n\nThose lucky enough to have balconies overlooking the beachfront held house parties to watch the show. Helicopters and drones flew overhead and motorboats and sailboats filled the bay, which meant the audience spanned land, air and sea.\n\nAt the start of the show, the 65-year-old told the crowd: \"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world. It is estimated that an additional 170 flights were landed at the city's airport as fans poured in from all over the world to attend the event.\n\nApproximately 1.6 million people attended the concert, some from brightly lit apartments and hotels overlooking the beach, while others from motorboats and sailboats anchored nearby.\n\nA dazzling show was put on by the singer, who played classics ranging from Like a Virgin to Like a Prayer and cycled through several sets and costumes.\n\nShe performed her 1997 hit Nothing Really Matters flanked by giant screens to a roar of approval from the audience.\n\nDuring her performance of Live to Tell, the singer also paid an emotional tribute to \"all the bright lights\" lost to Aids. {"uri": "8112611354", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "17:15:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T17:15:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T17:14:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.nydailynews.com/2024/05/05/madonna-celebration-rio-copacabana-dance-floor/", "title": "Madonna brings 1.6M people to Rio's Copacabana beach in record-setting tour finale", "body": "RIO DE JANEIRO -- Madonna knew they had been waiting -- and she made them dance, get up and do their thing.\n\nThe pop diva wrapped her critically acclaimed Celebration World Tour Saturday night with an emotional finale in front of 1.6 million fans on Rio de Janeiro's Copacabana beach.\n\nThe 81st and final show of Madonna's 12th concert tour -- which celebrated the artist's 40-year career and paid homage to her New York City roots -- gave concertgoers much of what they've come to expect since the show kicked off at the O2 Arena in London on Oct. 14: A theatrical spectacle, tear-inducing moments, a considerable late start and four decades of generation-defining hits.\n\nBut on Saturday, the Queen of Pop once again showed the world why she's still deserving of the title.\n\nAccording to the city's tourism agency RioTour, the crowd of 1.6 million fans who took over the sands and sidewalks of the world-famous beach -- about 100,000 more people than previously expected -- easily broke her previous record, when 130,000 fans saw her second music tour, Who's That Girl, in Paris in 1987.\n\nShe's also the first female artist to perform in front of an audience of 1 million people, according to Luiz Guilherme Niemeyer of Bonus Track, the Brazilian production company that brought Madonna to Rio.\n\nNearly 5,000 law enforcement officers were on standby for what some locals dubbed \"the show of the century.\" Several street blocks were completely taken by fans, many of whom camped out for days to secure a good viewing spot.\n\nBesides Madonna's faithful LGBTQ fan base -- several of them wearing clothing representative of a different Madonna era, such as Blond Ambition-themed cone bras or Erotica-days S&M gear -- Gen X mothers and their children danced to pop music classics including \"Everybody,\" Into the Groove,\" \"Vogue\" and \"Holiday.\"\n\nShe also paid tribute to all the lives lost to AIDS while singing \"Live to Tell\" during one of the show's more powerful moments.\n\nThe emotional and introspective moment consisted of photographs of Madonna's friends, mentors and fellow artists who died from the illness flashing on large screens behind her. On Saturday, that list also included late Brazilian artists, including the singers Cazuza, Renato Russo and the writer Caio Fernando de Abreu.\n\nLater in the show, Madonna welcomed to the stage Brazilian superstar Anitta, who served as a judge in the show's highly Instagrammable -- and often NSFW -- ballroom runway segment.\n\nPabllo Vittar, another Brazilian pop culture giant, also made a surprise appearance during Saturday's show. The global drag superstar helped Madonna kick the energy level into ecstasy levels as the duo sang Madonna's 2000 No. 1 hit \"Music,\" a new addition to the tour set list, alongside drum players from the city's samba schools.\n\nThe \"wonderful\" show proved that Madonna \"has always been ahead of her time,\" Mirelle de Fran\u00e7a, a 50-year-old journalist and longtime fan of the artist, told the Daily News.\n\n\"She was happy, radiant ... and made Rio happy,\" she added.\n\n\"Here we are in the most beautiful place in the world,\" Madonna told the audience at the beginning of the eagerly awaited performance that promised to turn Copacabana into \"the world's largest dance floor.\"\n\n\"This place is magic,\" she said, pointing out the ocean to her right, the mountains to her left and And those sales came thanks to her releasing 14 studio albums throughout her time in the spotlight. Often considered the \"Queen of Pop\", the singer was the first female to cross $1 billion in concert sales. During her first year of eligibility, the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inducted her. While 65 years old, Madonna recently showcased her massive appeal when her final stop of her Celebration Tour welcomed over one million fans.\n\nVideos by American Songwriter\n\nBack in March, Madonna shared her excitement when she announced her final show during her Celebration Tour would take place at Copacabana Beach. And to make it even better, the concert was free. Making her way to Rio de Janeiro on May 4, Madonna kept her promise of a free concert. But nobody expected close to two million people to attend. But that is exactly what happened. Continuing to showcase her star power, the free concert was Madonna's largest ever.\n\n[RELATED: Madonna is Getting Sued Again: Late Shows, Sweltering Venues, and Lip-Syncing]\n\nMadonna Recalls Fighting Bacterial Infection\n\nWanting to make the night special, Madonna performed some of her classic songs like \"Like A Virgin\", \"Into The Groove\", and \"Like A Prayer.\" While thrilled to perform in front of a sea of fans, Madonna almost ended her career on stage after battling a serious bacterial infection. Back in October, the hitmaker returned to the stage at London's O2 Arena. At the time, she explained how she almost lost her life. \"I didn't think I was gonna make it. Neither did my doctors. That's why I woke up with all of my children sitting around me.\"\n\nWhile focusing on her health, Madonna also praised divine intervention. \"The angels were protecting me, and my children were there. And my children always save me every time.\" Just last month, she once again praised her children when she wrote online, \"On the day before our 80th show of the Celebration Tour I need to acknowledge There was also a large police presence to ensure the safety of all those in attendance.\n\nT-shirts, souvenirs and billboards with Madonna's face decked the neighbourhood as excitement built ahead of the concert.\n\nSince she burst onto the UK charts with Holiday in 1984, Madonna has scored another 71 hits, including 13 number one singles.\n\nSome, like Vogue, Like A Prayer and Ray of Light, are era-defining anthems. On May 4, 2024, an estimated 1.6 million people gathered to witness the grand finale of the singer's Celebration Tour, marking the largest audience ever for a stand-alone concert. This achievement not only underscores Madonna's enduring appeal but also her unique connection with fans worldwide.\n\nThe concert was a heartfelt \"thank you\" to her followers, celebrating more than four decades of groundbreaking music. This place is magic.'\n\nShe was joined on stage by the likes of special guests including Diplo, Anitta, Pabllo Vittar and Bob the Drag Queen as she ran through her biggest hits including Like A Virgin, Hung Up and Live to Tell.\n\nIn an echo of previous show and her famous kiss with singer Britney Spears at the 2003 MTV VMAs, the chart-topper locked lips with a dancer as she grabbed her passionately.\n\nAt another point, Madonna also donned a Brazil football shirt as part of multiple costume changes which also included a metallic catsuit and red and black lace negligee.\n\nPictures of concertgoers - who covered a huge swathe of the beach - showed them well and truly in the mood for some Mage.\n\nPlenty were dressed up for the occasion with everything from homemade cone bras like the star's iconic Jean Paul Gaultier bustier, as well as plenty of blonde wigs and leather corsets.\n\nThe city's official tourism office, Visit Rio, had shared details prior to the concert, stating in a social media post: 'It's time to get ready! On May 4, the Queen of Pop arrives in Rio de Janeiro for a free and historic show at Copacabana Beach.\n\n'Madonna ends The Celebration Tour here in the Marvelous City, celebrating 40 years of her career with a show that promises to be her biggest.'\n\nThey had previously announced the huge free gig in March.\n\nThe Vogue hitmaker took to Instagram on Sunday with a clip of her performing song Music with a troupe of dancer and drummers.\n\n'Blame it on Rio. Thank You Brazil!!' she commented in the caption.\n\nHer Instagram Stories also revealed shots of her rehearsing ahead of the show, as well as a glimpse at her customised football shirt, emblazoned with 'Ciccone', her surname, across the back.\n\nMadonna has performed in the city three times before, in 1993, 2008 and 2012, playing in front of 120,000 at her first gig there.\n\nThe free show followed previous similar performances, including from the Rolling Stones, who played for 1,500,000 attendees on the beach back in 2006.\n\nSir Rod Stewart broke the record for the largest free rock concert when a whopping 4,200,000 revellers watched him in action at Copacabana on New Year's Eve in 1994.\n\nIf you've got a celebrity story, video or pictures get in touch with the Metro.co.uk obligatory given the unusual temperature of 30 degrees at this time -, mostly decorated with the colors of the rainbow.\n\nShortly before 11 p.m., the \"queen of pop,\" dressed all in black, appeared on stage performing \"Nothing Really Matters,\" a hymn to resilience.\n\n\"Here we are, Rio, the most beautiful place in the world!\": the diva delighted the Brazilian public for more than two hours.\n\nWith this concert announced for days as \"historic,\" the 65-year-old American pop star closed \"The Celebration Tour\" in style, touring the glory of his 40-year career, inventions, brilliance and scandals.\n\nOn a gigantic stage of more than 800 m2, he reviewed his heyday and the disconcerting series of his musical and sartorial metamorphoses, from pop to electronic music, passing through moments of cabaret inspiration.\n\nFlanked by several of her children, who accompanied her with music or dancing, Madonna was also honored by illustrious guests, with the Brazilian flag as a backdrop.\n\nWhen she performed her hit \"Vogue,\" she was joined on stage by Brazilian singer Anitta, who introduced Rio funk, the soundtrack of Rio's favelas, to the rest of the world.\n\nAlso present were drag queen Pabllo Vittar, a Brazilian pop star, and a group of children who played percussion in the city's famous samba schools.\n\nThe \"queen of pop\" also had a memory for the \"king of pop,\" Michael Jackson. A moment that has gone viral.\n\nIn the audience, fans from different generations talked about Madonna's place in their lives.\n\nAlba and Roxy Rueda, two Argentine sisters aged 48 and 46, bought their plane tickets as soon as the rumor of the concert emerged a few months ago.\n\n\"When I was nine years old, my older sister, who died last year, gave me my first Walkman with the cassette of Like a Virgin,\" the hit that Madonna released. \"Since then we have not stopped listening to it. Therefore, coming here is linked for us to our relationship as sisters,\" says Alba.\n\nTo increase the pressure before the concert, several DJs, including Diplo, an American turntable ace, took turns as night fell to bring joy to \"the largest dance floor in the world.\"\n\nThen the time came for the queen to leave her palace, or rather her palace: the mythical Copacabana Palace, a haven of peace and luxury for Hollywood and pop stars for decades, where she has established her family accommodation since the beginning of the week. .\n\nMadonna walked down a catwalk installed for the occasion, which took her directly to the stage.\n\nFor the event, the police were present in force, almost on all the streets of a neighborhood accustomed to crime, but also in the air with helicopters and drones.\n\nAfter 80 concerts in Europe, North America and Mexico, the Rio show serves as a finale, but also to clear up any doubts about his state of health. The rumors have not stopped since a serious bacterial infection landed the singer in intensive care in June 2023, terrifying her fans around the world.\n\nIn front of the Copacabana Palace and along the beach where souvenir sellers set up shop in Madonna's time and increased their stocks and prices, the atmosphere is festive in recent days and recalls the lightness of the Rio carnival, which ended almost ago. three months.\n\nThree planes and 270 tons of material landed in the \"Wonderful City\" with the American star, experienced in high-precision pyrotechnic shows.\n\nThe show was an important event for the city of Rio.
